publicationStmt.publisher: George Chapman, 1559?-1634 (1559?-1634) May-Day. A witty comedie, diuers times acted at the Blacke Fryers. VVritten by George Chapman London Printed for Iohn Browne [etc.] 1611

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
May-day. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1611. Date first performed: 1601-1602.

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Aurelio Angelo Gasparo Lodovico AEmilia Francischina Giacono Honorio Innocentio Fannio Leonoro Lorenzo Lionell Giovenelli Cuthbert Barber Lucretia/Lucretio Quintiliano A Tailor Tailors son Temperance A Drawer A messenger Another Woman Combined Voice

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Interim, Intrat Lorenzo Papers in his hand.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well done my lusty bloods, Well done. Fit, fit observance for this May-morning; Not the May month alone, they take when it comes; Nor the first week of that Month; Nor the first day; but the first minute of the first hour, of the first day. Lose no time bloods, lose no time; though the Sun go to bed never so much before you, yet be you up before him; call the golden sluggard from the silver arms of his Lady, to light you into yours, when your old father January here in one of his last days, thrusts his forehead into the depth of Mays fragrant bosom: What may you April's perform then? O what may you do? Well yet will I say thus much for myself, wheresoever the affections of youth are, there must needs be the instruments, and where the instruments are, there must of necessity be the faculties; What am I short of them then? A sound old man, ably constituted, wholesomely dieted, that took his May temperately at their ages, and continued his own; why should he not continue their ages in his own? By the Mass I feel nothing that stands against it, and therefore sweet May I salute thee with the youngest: I have love to employ thee in, as well as the proudest young princock, and so have at you Mistress Francischina have at you Mistress Franke: I will spread my nets for you i'faith, though they be my very purse nets, wherein what heart will not willingly lie panting?

sp.speaker: Ang.
Lor.
sp.p: Here have I put her face in rhyme, but I fear my old vain will not stretch to her contentment. O hair, no hair but beams stolen from the Sun.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Out upon her, if it be she that I think, she has a Fox red cranion;

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A forehead that disdains the name of fair.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: And reason, for it is a foul one.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A matchless eye.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: True, her eyes be not matches.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A cheek, vermilion red.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Painted I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A far commanding mouth.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: It stretches to her ears indeed .

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A nose made out of wax.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: A red nose, in sincerity.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: This could I send, but person, person does it: A good presence, to bear out a good wit; a good face, a pretty Court leg, and a deft dapper personage, no superfluous dimensions, but fluent in competence; for it is not Hector but Paris, not the full armful, but the sweet handful that Ladies delight in.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: O notable old whinyard.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Such a size of humanity now, and brain enough in it, it is not in the strength of a woman to withstand; well she may hold out a parley or two, for it is a weak fort that obeys at the first or second summons, if she resist the third she is discharged, though she yield in future: for then it appears it was no fault of hers: but the man that would take no denial. What rests now? means for access: True. O an honest Bawd were worth gold now.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: A plague upon him, I had thought to have appeared to him, but now if I do , he will take me for the man he talks on: I will therefore post by his dull eyesight, as in haste of business.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What Seignior Angelo? soft I command you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Gods precious, what mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I would be loath to be outrun I assure you Sir: was I able to stay you?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Your ability stood too stiff Sir, beshrew me else.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: O most offenceless fault, I would thou wouldst blaze my imperfection to one thou knowest, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well Sir another time, tell me where she is, and I will do so much for you gratis. Good morrow Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay stay good Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: My business says nay Sir, you have made me stay to my pain Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Not a whit man I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Go to then, briefly, to whom shall I commend your imperfections, will you tell me if I name her?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That I will, i'faith Boy.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Is not her hair, no hair, but beams stolen from the Sun?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Black, black as an Ouzel.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: A forehead that disdains the name of fair.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Away Witch, away:

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: A matchless eye.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Nay fie, fie, fie. I see thou art a very Devil Angelo. And in earnest, I jested, when I said my desire of thy friendship touched myself, for it concerns a friend of mine just
sp.l: of my standing.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: To whom then would he be remembered that I can solicit?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: To sweet Mistress Francischina with whom I hear thou art ready to lie down, thou art so great with her.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I am as great as a near Kinsman may be with her Sir, not otherwise:

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A good consanguinity: and good Angelo to her wilt thou deliver from my friend, in all secrecy, these poor brace of bracelets?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Perhaps I will Sir, when I know what the Gentleman and his intent is.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Never examine that man; I would not trouble you with carrying too much at once to her, only tell her, such a man will resolve her, naming me: and I do not greatly care, if I take the pains to come to her, so I stay not long, and be let in privily: and so without making many words: here they be, put them up closely I beseech thee, and deliver them as closely.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well Sir, I love no contention with friends, and therefore pocket many things, that otherwise I would not: but I pray Sir licence me a question. Do not I know this Gentleman that offers my Cozen this kindness?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Never sawest him in thy life, at least never knewest him; but for his bounty sake to all his well willers, if this message be friendly discharged, I may chance put a dear friend of him into your bosom: Sir, and make you profitably acquainted.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: But I pray you Sir, is he not a well elderly Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Wide, wide; as young as day, I protest to thee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I know he is young too, but that is in ability of body, but is he not a pretty little squat Gentleman, as you shall see amongst a thousand?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Still from the cushion, still, tall and high, like a Cedar.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I know he is tall also, but it is in his mind Sir, and it is not Hector but Paris, not thy full armful, but the sweet handful that a Lady delights to dandle.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Now the good Devil take thee, if there be any such in hell, hell I beseech thee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well, well Seignior Lorenzo, i'faith the little Squire is thought to be as peerless a piece of flesh, for a piece of flesh, as any hunts the hole pale of Venus I protest to ye.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I cannot contain myself, i'faith Boy, if the Wenches come in my walk, I give them that they come for, I dally not with them .

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I know you do not Sir, his dallying days be done.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: It is my infirmity, and I cannot do withal, to die for it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I believe you Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: There are certain envious old fellows, my neighbours, that say, I am one unwieldy and stiff: Angelo, didst ever hear any wench complain of my stiffness?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Never in my life: your old neighbours measure you by themselves.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why there is the matter then?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: But i'faith Sir: do you ever hope to win your purpose at my losing hands, knowing her (as all the world does) a woman of that approved lowliness of life, and so generally tried?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: As for that take thou no care, she is a woman, is she not?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Sure I do take her to have the flesh and blood of a woman.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Then good enough, or then bad enough, this token shall be my Gentleman Usher to prepare my access, and then let me alone with her.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Aye marry Sir, I think you would be alone with her; Well Sir, I will do my best, but if your Gentleman Usher should not get entrance for you now, it would be a grief
sp.l: to me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Fear it not man: Gifts and gold, take the strongest hold; Away, here comes a snudge that must be my son in law: I would be loath he should suspect these tricks of youth in me, for fear he fear my daughter will trot after me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Fare you well Sir.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Godge you God morrow Sir, godge you God morrow.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: God morrow neighbour Gasparo: I have talked with my daughter, whom I do yet find a green young plant, and therefore unapt to bear such ripe fruit, I think I might have said rotten, as yourself : But she is at my disposition, and shall be at yours in the end, here is my hand, and with my hand take hers.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Nay by my faith Sir, you must give me leave to shake her portion by the hand first.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: It is ready told for you Sir, come home when you will and receive it,
sp.p: and see, yonder she comes; away, she cannot yet abide you, because she fears she can abide you too well.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Well, I will come for her portion Sir, and till then, God take you to his mercy.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Adieu my good son in law, I will not interrupt her, let her meditate a my late motion.

sp.speaker: AEmi.
sp.l: it is strange to see the impiety of parents,
Both privileged by custom, and professed,
The holy institution of heaven;
Ordaining marriage for proportioned minds,
For our chief human comforts; and to increase
The loved images of God in men:
Is now perverted to the increase of wealth;
We must bring riches forth, and like the Cuckoo
Hatch others eggs; Join house to house, in choices
Fit timber-logs and stones, not men and women:
Aye me, here is one I must shun, would embrace.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O stay and hear me speak or see me die.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: How now? what have we here? what a loathsome creature man is being drunk: Is it not pity to see a man of good hope, a toward Scholar, writes a theme well, scans a verse very well, and likely in time to make a proper man, a good leg, specially in a boot, valiant, well spoken, and in a word, what not? and yet all this overthrown as you see, drowned, quite drowned in a quart pot.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.l: O these same wicked healths, breed monstrous diseases.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Aurelio speak man, Aurelio?

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.l: Pray heaven all be well.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O speak, if any spark of speech remain.
It is thy dear AEmilia that calls.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Well, well, it becomes not a friend to touch the deadly wounds of his friend with a smiling countenance.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Touch thee? 'sblood I could find in my heart to beat thee;up in a fools name, up: what a Scene of foppery have we here?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: prithee have done.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Up Cuckoo, Cupids bird, or by this light I will fetch thy father to thee.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Good Lodouico, if thou lovest me, leave me; thou comest to counsel me from that, which is joined with my soul in eternity: I must and will do what I do.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Do so then, and I protest thou shalt never lick thy lips after my Kinswoman, while thou livest: I had thought to have spoken for thee, if thou hadst taken a manly course with her: but to fold up thyself like an Urchin, and lie a-calving to bring forth a husband: I am ashamed to think on it: 'sblood I have heard of wenches that have been won with singing and dancing, and some with riding, but never heard of any that was won with tumbling in my life.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: If thou knewest how vain thou seemest.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I do it of purpose, to show how vain I hold thy disease, 'Sheart art thou the first that has shot at a wenches heart and missed it? must that shot that missed her wound thee? let her shake her heels in a shrews name: were she my Cozen a thousand times, and if I were as thee, I would make her shake her heels too, afore I would shake mine thus.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O vanity, vanity.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, if any wench should offer to keep possession of my heart against my will, I would fire her out with Sack and Sugar, or smoke her out with Tobacco, like a hornet, or purge for her, for love is but a humour: one way or other I would vent her, that is infallible.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: For shame hold thy tongue, methinks thy wit should feel how stale are these love storms, and with what general privilege love pierces the worthiest. Seek to help thy friend, not mock him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Marry, seek to help thyself then, in a halters name, do not lie in a ditch, and say God help me, use the lawful tools he hath lent thee. Up I say I will bring thee to her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: She will not endure me:

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: She shall endure thee do the worst thou canst to her, I and endure thee till thou canst not endure her; But then thou must use thyself like a man, and a wise man, how deep soever she is in thy thoughts, carry not the prints of it in thy looks ; be bold and careless, and stand not sautering afar off , as I have seen you, like a Dog in a firme-typot, that licks his chops and wags his tail, and fain would lay his lips to it, but he fears it is too hot for him: that is the only way to make her too hot for thee. He that holds religious and sacred thought of a woman, he that bears so reverend a respect to her, that he will not touch her but with a kissed hand and a timorous heart; he that adores her like his Goddess: Let him be sure she will shun him like her slave. Alas good souls, women of themselves are tractable and tactable enough, and would return Quid for Quod still, but we are they that spoil them , and we shall answer for it another day. We are they that put a kind of wanton Melancholy into them, that makes them think their noses bigger than their faces, greater than the Sun in brightness; and where as Nature made them but half fools, we make them all fool. And this is our palpable flattery of them, where they had rather have plain dealing Well, in conclusion, I will to her instantly, and if I do not bring her to thee, or at the lest some special favour from her, as a feather from her fan, or a string from her shoe, to wear in thy hat, and so forth, then never trust my skill in poultry whilst thou livest again.

body.stage: Enter Quintiliano, Innocentio, Fransischma, Angelo, and Fannio.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Thou shalt not to the wars, or if thou dost I will bear thee company, dear Quint, do not offer to forsake me.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Hands off wife, hang not upon me thus; how can I maintain thee but by using my valour? and how can I use that, but in action and employment? go in, play at cards with your Cozen Angelo here, and let it suffice I love thee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come sweet Cozen, do not cloy your husband with your love so, especially to hinder his preferment; who shall the Duke have to employ in these Marshall necessities if not Captain Quintiliano? he bears an honourable mind, and it is pity but he should have employment. Let him get a company now, and he will be able to maintain you like a Duchess hereafter.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Well said Seignior Angelo, God save me you speak like a true Cozen indeed, does he not Quint?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: He does so, and I thank him; yet see how the fool puts finger in the eye still.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will cheer her up, I warrant you Captain; come Cuz, let us in to tables.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Farewell sweet Mistress.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Farewell my good servant.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Now take away thy hand, and show thou didst laugh all this while; good Lord who would not marry to have so kind a wife make much on him?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: After Boy, give your attendance.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.l: Could you not spare me money for mine hostess, where you put me to board? you are a whole fortnight in arrearages.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Attend I say, the hostess of the Lion has a leg like a Giant, want for nothing Boy, so she score truly.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: Faith Sir, she has chalked it up twenty shillings already, and swears she will chalk no more.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Then let her choke, and choke thou with her: 'sblood hobby horse, and she had chalked up twenty pounds, I hope the world knows I am able to pay it with a wet finger.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.l: Alas Sir, I think you are able, but the world does not know it.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Then the worlds an ignorant Sir, and you are an innocent, vanish Boy, away.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.l: I hope he will foist some money for my score, out of this gull here.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: It is a plaguey good wag Quint, is it not?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: I will make him a good one ere I have done with him; but this same loving fool my wife now, will never leave weeping, till I make her believe I will not have a company. Who would be cumbered with these soft hearted creatures, that are ever in extremes, either too kind, or too unkind?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Save me, it is true, it is a hard thing must please them in sadness.

sp.speaker: Quint.
Innoc.
sp.l: Nay sweet Quint, then how shall I be a Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Well, and my promise were not past to thee, I am a villain if all the world should part Franke and me; think I love thee therefore, and will do thee credit: It will cost me a great deal of this same foolish money to buy me drum and ensign, and furnish me thoroughly, but the best is I know my credit.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: 'sfoot Quint, we will want no money man, I will make my row of houses fly first.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Let them walk; Candle rents: if the wars hold, or a plague come to the town, they will be worth nothing.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: True, or while I am beyond Sea, some sleepy wench may set fire in the bed-straw.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Right, or there may come an earthquake, and overturn them .

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Just, or there may be conjuring, and the wind may down with them .

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Or some crafty pettifogger may find a hole in the title, a thousand casualties belongs to them.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Nay, they shall walk, that is certain, I will turn them into money.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: That is thy most husbandly course i'faith Boy, thou mayst have twenty in the hundred for thy life, I will be thy man for two hundred.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Will it i'faith Quint? God save me it is done.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: For your life, not otherwise.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Well, I desire no more, so you will remember me for my Lieutenantship.

sp.speaker: Quint.
Innoc.
sp.l: If you have a company Captain.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: If I have: damn me if such another word do not make me put thee out of the place again; if I have a company, 'sfoot, let the Duke deny me one, I would it were come to that once, that employment should go with the undeserver, while men of service sit at home, and feed their anger with the blood of red lattices. Let the Duke deny me today , I will renounce him tomorrow .I will to the enemy point blank, I am a villain else:

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: And I by heaven I swear.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Well if that day come, it will prove a hot day with somebody .

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: But Captain, did not you say that you would enter me at an Ordinary, that I might learn to converse?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: When thou wilt Lieutenant; no better time than now, for now thou art in good clothes, which is the most material point for thy entrance there.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Aye but how should I behave myself ?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Marry Sir, when you come first in, you shall see a crew of Gallants of all sorts:

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Nay Captain if I come first in I shall see nobody .

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Tush man, you must not do so, if you have good clothes and will be noted let am all come in assure you, and then as I said shall you see a lusty crew of Gallants, some Gentlemen, some none; but that is all one: he that bears himself like a Gentleman, is worthy to have been borne a Gentleman: some aged have beards, and some have none, some have money, and some have none, yet all must have meat: Now will all these I say at your first entrance wonder at you, as at some strange Owl: Examine your person, and observe your bearing for a time. Do you then at the the other side seem to neglect their observance as fast, let your countenance be proof against all eyes, not yielding or confessing in it any inward defect. In a word be impudent enough, for that is your chief virtue of society.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Is that? faith and I need not learn that, I have that by nature I thank God.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: So much the better, for nature is far above Art, or judgment. Now for your behaviour; let it be free and negligent, not clogged with ceremony or observance, give no man honour, but upon equal terms; for look how much thou givest any man above that, so much thou takest from thyself : he that will once give the wall, shall quickly be thrust into the kennel: measure not thy carriage by any man's eye, thy speech by no man's ear, but be resolute and confident in doing and saying, and this is the grace of a right Gentleman as thou art.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: 'sfoot, that I am I hope, I am sure my father has been twice Warden of his company.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: That is not a peer matter man, there is no prescription for Gentility, but good clothes and impudence: for your place, take it as it falls, but so as you think no place too good for you; fall too with ceremony whatsoever the company be: and as near as you can, when they are in their Mutton, be thou in thy Woodcock, it shows resolution. Talk any thing, thou carest not what, so it be without offence, and as near as thou canst without sense.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Let me alone for that Captain I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: If you chance to tell a lie, you must bind it with some oath, as by this bread, for breads a binder you know.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: And yet take heed you swear by no man's bread but your own, for that may breed a quarrel: above all things you must carry no coals.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: By heaven not I, I will freeze to death first.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Well Sir, one point more I must remember you of. After dinner there will be play, and if you would be counted complete, you must venture amongst them; for otherwise, they will take you for a Scholar or a Poet, and so fall into contempt of you: for there is no virtue can scape the accompt of baseness if it get money, but gaming and law; yet must you not lose much money at once, for that argues little wit at all times.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: As God save me, and that is my fault; for if I be in once, I shall lose all I have about me.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Is true, Lieutenant? by Our Lady Sir I will be your moderator, therefore let me see how much money have you about you?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Not much, some twenty mark or twenty pound in gold.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: It is too much to lose by my faith, Lieutenant; give me your purse Sir, hold ye, here is two brace of Angels, you shall venture that for fashion sake, I will keep the rest for you, till you have done play.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: That will be all one, for when that is lost I shall never leave till I get the rest from you: for I know thou wilt let me have it if I ask it.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Not a penny by this gold.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: prithee do not then, as God save me and you do:

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: And I do, hang me; Come let us to the Duke.

body.stage: Enter Lucretia and Temperance, severall wayes.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Nay Mistress, pray even go in again, for I have some inward news for you.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: What are those pray.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: It is no matter Mistress till you come in, but make much a time in the mean time, good fortune thrusts herself upon you in the likeness of a fine young Gentleman, hold up your apron and receive him while you may, in Gods name.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: How say by that? you are a very wise counselor.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.l: Well Mistress, when I was a Maid, and that is a good while ago I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: I think very well.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.l: You were but a little one then iwis.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Nor you neither I believe.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.l: Faith it is one of the furthest things I can remember.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: But what when you were a Maid?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Marry Mistress I took my time, I warrant you. And there is Seignior Leonora now, the very flower of Venice, and one that loves you dearly I ensure you.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: God forgive him if he do, for I will be sworn I never deserved his love, nor never will while I live.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Why then, what say to Seignior Collainte? there is a dainty piece of Venison for you, and a fervent lover indeed.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: He? I dare say, he knows not what wood loves shafts are made of, his Seigniory would think it the deepest disparagement could be done to him, to say that ever he spent sigh for any Dame in Italy.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Well, you have a whole browne dozen a suitors at least, I am sure; take your choice amongst them all, if you love not all, yet you may love three or four of them to be doing withal.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: To be doing withal? love three or four?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Why not, so you love them moderately. What must that strange made piece Theagines that you cry out upon so often, have all from other, and yet know not where he is?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: O my Theagines, not Theagines, thy love hath turned me woman like thyself , shall thy sight never turn me man again. Come let us to the Minster, God hear my prayers as I intend to stop mine ears against all my suitors.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.l: Well Mistress, yet peradventure, they may make you open afore the Priest have a penny for you.

sp.speaker: Lodo.
sp.p: Here is a coil to make wit and women friends: come hither wench, let me have thee single; now sit thee down, and hear good counsel next thy heart, and God give thee grace to lay it to thy heart.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Fie Cozen, will this wild tongue of yours never receive the bridle?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yes, thou shalt now see me stroke my beard, and speak sententiously: thou tellest me thy little father is in hand with a great rich marriage for thee, and would have thee commit matrimony with old Gasparo, art thou willing with it?

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: I rather wish myself married to a thousand deaths.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Then I perceive thou knowest him not; did he never woo thee?

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: I protest, I never changed three words with him in my life; he hath once or twice wooed my father for me, but never me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why that is the reason thou lovest him not, because thou takest in none of his valiant breath to inflame thee, nor vouchsafest his knowledge; I will tell thee what he is, an old sapless trunk, fit to make touch-wood of hollow, and bald like a blasted Oak, on whose top Ravens sit and croak the portents of funerals; one that noints his nose with clotted cream, and His breath smells like the butt end of a shoe-makers horn. A leprous scaly hide like an Elephant. The son of a Sow-gelder, that came to town (as I have heard thy father himself say) in a tottered russet cote, high shoes, and yet his hose torn above them ; A long pike-staff in his neck (and a turd in his teeth) and a wallet on his right shoulder, and now the cullion hath with Nouerint uniuersi eaten up some hundred Gentlemen: he must needs rise a Gentleman as it were out of their Ashes, or disparage a Gentlewoman, to make himself a Gentleman, at least by the wives side.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: The worse my fortune to be entangled with such a winding bramble.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Entangled? Nay if I thought it would ever come to that, I would hire some shag-rag or other for half a chicken to cut his throat, only to save thy hands from doing it; for I know thou wouldst poison him within one month; love thee he will never, and that must be thy happiness: for if he do, look to be cooped up like a prisoner, condemned to execution, scarce suffered to take the air, so much as at a window, or waited on continually by an old beldam: not to keep thee company, but to keep thee from company: thy pocket searched, thy cabinets ransacked for letters: ever in opposition, unless (like the Moon) once a Month in conjunction; wealth thou mayst have indeed, but enjoy it as in a dream, for when thou wakest thou shalt find nothing in thy hand;
and (to keep my tale in goodness) see how all the ill that can be spoken of him is expressed in his presence.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: O ugly, and monstrous spectacle.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Now tell me whether thou wouldst make choice of him or a young gallant in prime of his choiceness; one that for birth, person, and good parts, might meritoriously marry a Countess; and one to whom his soul is not so dear as thyself .
For all the world such another as he that comes here now: mark him well, see whether Gasparo and he be not a little different.
sp.l: How now? 'swounds, Aurelio? stay beast, wilt thou make such a blessed opportunity curse thee? I will fetch her out to thee.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Wretch that I am, how she loathes me? if I abide her, I shall consume in the lightnings of her anger.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Here is a life indeed ; what is he gone? passion of death, what a babe it is? I could find in my heart to jerk him, but temper me friendship, no remedy now; now wit turn his defects to perfection. Why Cuz he is quite out of sight. By my life I commend him; why this is done like thyself Aurelio, were she the Queen of love and would run from thee, fly thou from her; why now I love thee, for I see thou art worthy of my love, thou carriest a respect to thine own worth, and wilt express it with spirit; I dare say, thou lookest to have had him fall on his knees, and adored thee, or beg his life at thy hands: or else turned Queen Dido, and pierce his tender heart with sword full sharpe; no, faith wench, the case is altered, love made spin, but it made him rage after: there must go time to the bridling of every passion; I hope my friend will not love a wench against her will, if she would have met his kindness half way, so: if she skit and recoil, he shoots her off warily, and away he goes: Aye marry Sir, this was a Gentlemanly part indeed . Farewell Cuz, be thou free in thy choice too, and take a better if thou canst in Gods name.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Nay dear Cuz, a word.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: A word? what is the matter? I must needs after him, and clap him on the back , this spirit must be cherished.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Alas what would you wish me to do?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why, nothing.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Would you counsel me to marry him against my fathers will?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Not for the world, leave him, leave him, leave him: you see he is resolved, he will take no harm an you, never fear to imbrue your hands with his liver I warrant you.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Come you are such an other.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: This same riches with a husband, is the only thing in the world, I protest; good Gasparo, I am sorry I have abused thee i'faith, for my Cozens sake; how prettily the wretch came crawling by with his crooked knees even now: I have seen a young Gentlewoman, live as merry a life with an old man, as with the proudest young upstart of them all: farewell Cuz, I am glad thou art so wise i'faith.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.p: If you go, I die: fie on this affection, it rageth with suppression. Good Cuz, I am no longer able to continue it, I love Aurelio better than it is possible for him to love me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Away, away, and could not this have been done at first, without all these superfluous disgracings? O this same unhearty niceness of women, is good for nothing but to keep their housewife hands still occupied in this warp of dissembling. Well wench redeem thy fault, and write a kind letter to him presently, before this resolution of his take too deep root in him.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.p: Nay sweet Cuz, make me not so immodest, to write so suddenly, let me have a little time to think upon it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Think me on nothing till you write: think as you write, and then you shall be sure to write as you think . Women do best when they least think on it.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: But rather than write I will meet him at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Meet him? dost thou think that I shall ever draw him again to meet thee, that rushed from thee even now with so just a displeasure?

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Nay good Cuz, urge not my offence so bitterly, our next meeting shall pay the forfeit of all faults.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well thou art my pretty Cuz, and I will do my best to bring him to thee again, if I cannot, I shall be sorry i'faith, thou wert so injuriously strange to him. But where shall this interview be now.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.p: There is the mischief, and we shall hardly avoid it, my father plies my haunts so closely: and uses means by our maid to entrap us, so that this Tarrasse at our back gate is the only place we may safely meet at: from whence I can stand and talk to you. But sweet Cuz you shall swear, to keep this my kindness from Aurelio, and not intimate by any means that I am any thing acquainted with his coming.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'slife, dost think I am an Ass? to what end should I tell him? he and I will come wandering that way to take the air, or so, and I will discover thee.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: By mere chance as it were .

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: By chance, by chance, and you shall at no hand see him at first, when I bring him for all this kindness you bear him.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: By no means Cuz.

sp.speaker: Lod.
m.
sp.l: If do not Cuz, trust me not.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Or if you think good, you may flirt away again as soon as you see him, and never let your late fault be any warning to ye.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: I will do all this, I warrant thee Cuz.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Will you so Cozen fool? canst thou be brought to that silly humour again by any persuasions? by Gods Lord, if you be strange again, more than needs must, for a temperate modesty, I will break his neck down from thee, but he shall do as he did to thee.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Now, fie upon you Cuz, what a fool do you make me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well Dame, leave your superfluous nicety in earnest, and within this hour I will bring him to this Tarrasse.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: But good Cuz if you chance to see my chamber window open, that is upon the Tarrasse, do not let him come in at it in any case.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'Sblood how can he? can he come over the wall thinkst?

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: O Sir, you men have not devices with ladders of ropes to scale such walls at your pleasure, and abuse us poor wenches.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Now a plague of your simplicity, would you discourage him with prompting him? well Dame, I will provide for you.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: As you love me Cuz, no words of my kindness from me to him.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Go to, no more ado.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.l: God ye God morrow Sir, truly I have not heard a sweeter breath than your Page has.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am glad you like him Mistress Temperance

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.l: And how do ye Sir?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That I must know of you Lady, my welfare depends wholly upon your good speed.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: How say Sir? and by my soul I was coming to you in the morning when your young man came to me; I pray let him put on, unless it be for your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He is young, and can endure the cold well enough bareheaded.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.l: A pretty sweet child it is I promise you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But what good news Mistress Temperance, will your Mistress be won to our kind meeting?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Faith I will tell you Sir, I took her in a good mood this morning, and broke with her again about you, and she was very pleasant as she will be many times.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Very well, and is there any hope of speed?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: No by my troth Gentleman, none in the world, an obstacle young thing it is, as ever I broke with all in my life: I have broke with a hundred in my days, though I say it, yet never met her comparison.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Are all my hopes come to this Mistress Temperance?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Nay it is no matter Sir, this is the first time that ever I spake to any in these matters, and it shall be the last God willing.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And even now she had broke with a hundred and a hundred.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.l: But do you love her Sir indeed?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Dost thou make a question of that?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Pardon me I pray Sir, I mean do ye love her as a Gentleman ought to do, that is, to consummate matrimony with her as they say?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: That is no matter to you Mistress Temperance, do you procure our meeting, and let my favour be at her hands as I can enforce it.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: You say like an honest Gentleman; a woman can have no more: and faith Sir I wish you well, and every day after dinner my Mistress uses to go to her chair or else lie down upon her bed, to take a nap or so, to avoid idleness as many good housewives do, you know, and then do I sit by her and few, or so: and when I see her fast asleep, Lord do I think to myself, (as you know we waiting women have many light thoughts in our heads) Now if I were a man, and should bear my Mistress an ill will, what might I do to her now.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Indeed then you have very good opportunity.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: The best that may be, for she sleeps like a sucking Pig, you may jog her a hundred times, and she will stir no more than one of your stones, here.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And could you put a friend in your place think you?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Nay by Our Lady Sir, back with that leg, for if anything come on it but well, all the burthen will lie upon me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why what can come of it? only that by this means I may solicit her love myself.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.l: Aye but who knows if the Devil (God bless us) should be great with ye, how you would use her?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What dost thou take me for a beast, to force her that I would make my wife?

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: Beast Sir; Nay there is no beastliness in it neither, for a man will show like a man in those cases: and besides, you may mar the bed, which everybody will see that comes in; and that I would not for the best gown I shall were this twelve Month.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Well, to put thee out of that fear, it shall be worth such a gown to thee.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.p: I thank you for that Sir, but that is all one, and thus Sir, my old Master Honorio, at two a clock will be at Tilting, and then will his son Seignior Aurelio, and his man Angelo, be abroad; at which hour if you will be at the back gate, and muffle yourself handsomely, you may linger there till I call you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Aye marry Sir, so I may be there long enough.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.l: Nay, but two o'clock , now, now is my hour Sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Very well, and till then farewell.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.l: Boy to you heartily.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Boy to him indeed if he knew all.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I have provided thee a ladder of ropes, therefore resolve to meet her, go wash thy face, and prepare thyself to die, I will go make ready the ladder.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: But when is the happy hour of our meeting?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Marry Sir, that is something uncertain, for it depends wholly upon her fathers absence, and when that will be God knows: but I doubt not it will happen once within this twelve-month.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: 'swounds a twelve-month.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay hark you, you are all upon the spur now, but how many lovers have served seven twelve-months prenticeships, for the freedom of their Mistress favours? notwithstanding to shorten your torments, your man Angelo must be the mean, to draw the lap wing her father from his nest, by this device that I tell you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I did ever dream that once in my life good fortune would warm her cold hand in my naked bosom. And that once is now come, I will lay hold upon it , i'faith; I have you my little squire, I have you upon mine Anvil, upon which I will mallet you and work you; coining crowns, chickens, bracelets, and what not out of you; for procuring you the dear gullage of my sweet heart mistress Francischina.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.p: I am glad it rests in my kind servant Angelo, ~~ Angelo, well met, it lies in thee now, make me no more thy master, but thy friend, and forever happy in thy friendship.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: In what part of me does that lie Sir, that I may pull it out, for you presently?

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: My friend Ludouico here hath told me, what thou revealedest to him today , touching his uncle Lorenzo, and his love suit to Francischina.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Slight I told it him in secret sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And so did I tell it him Angelo, I am a Jew else.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: It may well be sir, but what of that?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: This Angelo, he would have thee procure my old uncles absence from home this afternoon, by making him meet or pretending his meeting with his mistress, and thy sweet heart, Francischina.

sp.speaker: Aure.
sp.l: Which if thou dost Angelo, be sure of reward to thy wishes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What talk you of reward sir? to the loving and dutiful servant, it is a greater encouragement to his service to hear his master say, God a mercy Angelo, spy out Angelo, I will think of thy pains one day Angelo, then all your base rewards and preferments: yet not to hinder your hand sir, I will extend mine to his service presently, and get your old uncle (seignior Lorenzo) out of the ways long enough I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: It is honestly said, which when thou hast performed, enforce us

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I will not fail sir, I was resolved to make him away afore they spake to me, in procuring his access to Francischina, for what is his presence at her house, but his absence at his owns? and thus shall I with one trowel daub two walls,

see how fitly she meets me. I will stand close here as if it were in my shop of good fortune, and; in respect of all ornaments I can help her to, I will out of the fulness of my joy, put her out of her study and encounter her thus;
Do ye lack gentlewoman, do ye lack? very fair new gowns, kirtles, petticoats, wrought smocks, bracelets, do ye lack gentlewoman, do ye lack?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What means my love by these strange salutations?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Prithee ask me no questions; hold take these bracelets, put up this purse of gold quickly, and if thou wilt have any of these things, I have cried to thee, speak and it is performed.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: From whose treasury comes all this, I prithee?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Lorenzo, Lorenzo a gentleman of much antiquity, and one that for his love hath burned hundreds of hearts to powder; yet now it falls out, that his tree of life is scorched and blasted with the flames of thy beauty, ready to wither eternally, unless it be speedily comforted with the sweet drops of thy nose.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Gods my life, is that old squire so amorous?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You wrong him to term him old, he can draw his bow, ride his horse, use his sword, and trail his pike under Loves colours, as well as ever he did.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: I believe that easily.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well, go thy ways in and prepare to entertain him now thy husband is from home, only with good words, and best kindnesses, making him put all into deeds till his treasury be deedless.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You speak as if I had nothing to respect but his entertainment, when you know how close and timely it must be put in execution, considering with what envious eyes my neighbours survey me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Thinkst thou, I consider not all this? he shall come in disguised, wench, and do thou devise for our mirth, what ridiculous disguise he shall come in, and he shall assume it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: What a magnifico of the City, and one of the Senate, thinkest thou he will not see into that inconvenience?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No more than no Senator, for in this case, my assurance is that Cupid will take the scarf from his own eyes, and hoodwink the old buzzard, while two other true turtles enjoy their happiness: get thee in I beseech thee love , tell thy gold, and say thy prayers.
sp.l: Now for a far fetched device to fetch over my love squire.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I see him within earshot; well may beauty inflame others, riches may tempt others; but for me, mine ears and mine eyes, are proof against all the Sirens, and Venuses, in all the seas of the world; beauty is a whore, riches a bawd, and I will trust none of you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What ails poor Angelo?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nay mistress Franke, if you prove disloyal once, farewell all constancy in women.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How now man? what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: O Sir are you so near? I shall trust your experience in women the better while I live.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I prithee why so?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Say true Sir, did you never solicit your love suit to fair mistress Francischina.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Never I protest Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Upon my life it is a strange thing; I would have sworn all Italy, could not so suddenly have fastened a favour upon her, I looked for a siege of Troy at least, to surprise the turrets of her continence; but to yield at the first sight of her assailants colours, and before any Cannon was mounted afore her, it is one of the loosest parts of a modest woman that ever I heard of.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How sayst thou? did not I tell thee as much? beware of an old colt while you live, he can tell when to strike I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Women and feathers? now fie on that affinity.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Alas Angelo, a feeble generation, soon overcome God knows, the honester mind, the sooner overcome.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Gods my life, what light housewife would yield at first to a stranger, and yet does this whirligig stand upon terms of honour forsooth? tenders her reputation as the Apple of her eye; she has a jealous and a cutting husband, envious neighbours, and will die many deaths rather then by any friends open access to her, be whipped naked with the tongues of scandal and slander; and a whole sanctuary of such ceremonies.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: O she does worthily in that Angelo, and like a woman of honour, thou hast painted her perfection in her faults thou findest, and ticklest me with her appetite.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And to avoid all sight of your entrance, you must needs come in some disguise she says; so much she tenders your high credit in the City, and her own reputation, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How, come in some disguise?

sp.speaker: Ang
sp.p: A toy, a very toy which runs in her head with such curious feet Sir, because if there be any resemblances of your person seen to enter her house, your whole substantial self will be called in question; any other man she says, might better adventure with the least thing changed about them than you with all; as if you were the only noted mutton-monger in all the City.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well Angelo, heaven forgive us the sins of our youth.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: That is true Sir, but for a paltry disguise, being a magnifico, she shall go snick up.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Soft good Angelo, soft, let us think on it a little: what disguise would serve the turn says she?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Faith, I know not what disguise she would have for you: she would have you come like a Calf with a white face, I think, she talks of Tinkers, peddlers, porters, chimney-sweepers, fools and Physicians, such as have free egress and regress into men's houses without suspicion.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Out upon them, would she have me undergo the shame and hazard of one of those abjects?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: i'faith I told her so, a squire of that worship, one of the Senate, a grave Justicer, a man of wealth, a magnifico?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And yet by my troth, for the safeguard of her honour, I would do much; methinks a Friars weed were nothing.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Out upon it , that disguise is worn thread bare upon every stage, and so much villainy committed under that habit; that it is grown as suspicious as the vilest. If you will hearken to any, take such a transformance, as you may be sure will keep you from discovery: for though it be the stale refuge of miserable Poets, by change of a hat or a cloak, to alter the whole state of a Comedy, so as the father must not know his own child forsooth, nor the wife her husband, yet you must not think they do it earnest to carry it away so: for say you were stuffed into a motley coat, crowded in the case of a bass Viol, or buttoned up in a cloak-bag, even to your chin, yet if I see your face, I am able to say this is seignior Lorenzo, and therefore unless your disguise be such that your face may bear as great a part in it as the rest, the rest is nothing.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Good reason, in faith Angelo, and what, shall I then smirch my face like a chimney sweeper, and; wear the rest of his smokiness?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I will tell you sir, if you be so mad to condescend to the humour of a foolish woman, by consideration that Jove for his love took on him the shape of a Bull, which is far worse than a chimney sweeper, I can fit you rarely.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: As how I prithee?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: There is one little Snail you know, an old chimney sweeper.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What, he that sings, Maids in your smocks, hold open your locks, fluds.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: The very same sir, whose person (I borrowing his words) you will so lively resemble, that himself in person cannot detect you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: But is that a fit resemblance to please a lover Angelo?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: For that sir, she is provided: for you shall no sooner enter but off goes your rusty scabbard, sweet water is ready to scour your filthy face, milk, and; a bath of fernebraks for your fusty body, a chamber perfumed, a wrought shirt, night cap, and her husbands gown, a banquet of Oysters pies, Potatoes, Skirret roots, Oranges, and divers other whetstones of venery.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: O let me hug thee Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: A bed as soft as her hair, sheets as delicate as her skin, and as sweet as her breath, pillows imitating her breasts, and her breasts to boot, Hippocras in her cups, and Nectar in her lips, Ah, the gods have been beasts for less felicity.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Angelo no more good no more, how shall I requite the happiness thou wilt bring me to ? hast any mind of marriage?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Not much sir, but an extraordinary wife might tempt me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: By my troth if she were not promised, thou shouldest have my daughter: but come let us to our disguise, in which I long to be singing.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will follow you presently.
Seignior Lodouico

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How now Angelo?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Why sir, I am providing means to lead your old uncle out of the way, as you willed me, by drawing him into the way of Quintuilanoes wife, my sweet heart, and so make room for him by Quintilanoes room: you that lead him any way, must needs seek him out and employ him to some tavern.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: He will be with me presently Angelo, and here is a freshman come from Padua, whom I will powder with his acquaintance, and so make him an excellent morsel to relish his carouses.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Go to Sir, by this light you will be complained on, there cannot be a fool within twenty mile of your head, but you engross him for your own mirth: Noblemen's tables cannot be served for you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'sfoot, I will complain of them man, they hunt me out and hang upon me, so that I cannot be rid of them , but they shall get somebody else to laugh at, or I will turn them over to our Poets, and make all the world laugh at them .

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well Sir, here comes your man, make him sure from his wife, and I will make the the other sure with her.

body.stage: Enter Quintiliano, Innocentio, Fannio, Taylor, Taylors sonne, he Reades a bill.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: See Seignior Gionanelle, here comes the famous Captain you would so fain be acquainted withal; be acquainted with him at your peril: I will defend you from his swaggering humour, but take heed of his cheating.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: I warrant you Sir, I have not been matriculated at the University, to be matriculated by him: salted there to be colted here.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Very well Sir, let us hear him.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.p: I have examined the particulars of your bill Master Taylor, and I find them true Orthography, thy payment shall be correspondent: marry I will set no day, because I am loath to break.

sp.speaker: Tailor.
sp.p: Alas Sir, pray let this be the day: consider my charge, I have many children, and this my poor child here whom I have brought up at school, must lose all I have bestowed on him hitherto, if I pay not his Master presently the quarterage I owe him.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Fool dost thou delight to hear thy son beg in Latin, pose him Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: How make you this in Latin boy? My father is an honest Taylor.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: That will hardly be done in true Latin Sir.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: No? why so Sir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Because it is false English sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: An excellent Boy.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Why is it false English?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Marry sir, as bona Mulier is said to be false Latin, because though bona be good, Mulier is naught; so to say my father is an honest Taylor, is false English; for though my father be honest, yet the Taylor is a thief.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Believe it a rare shred, not of homespun cloth upon my life: Taylor, go, send the schoolmaster to me at night and I will pay him.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Thank you good Captain, and if you do not pay him, at night my wife will come to you herself, that is certain, and you know what a tongue she has.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Like the sting of a Scorpion, she nails mine ears to the pillory with it, in the shame and torment she does me. Go I will void this Bill and avoid her.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Lieutenant, is not this a brave gullery? The slave has a pretty wife, and she will never have me pay him, because she may ever come to my chamber, as she says, to rail at me, and then she goes home and tells her husband she has tickled me i'faith.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: By my life, a rare jest.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Thou mayst see this Boy is no shred of a Taylor, is he not right of my look and spirit?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Right as a line, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: And will agree in the halter.~~ Save you Captain Quintiliano.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: And dost thou live my noble Lodouico? Boy, take my cloak, when shall us have a rouse, have? my Lieutenant and I were drunk last night, with drinking health on our knees to thee.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: Why, would not your legs bear you Sir?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: How many miles to midsummer? 'sblood, whose fool are you? are not you the tassel of a Gander?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: No indeed not I Sir: I am your poor friend Sir glad to see you in health.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Health? 'Sfoot, how mean you that? do you think I came lately out of the powdering Tub?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: God save me Sir it was the furthest part of my thought.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Why you are not angry, are you?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: No, nor you shall not be.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: 'sblood, I hope I may and I will.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Be and you dare Sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Dare?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Aye , dare.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Plague on thee, thou art the maddest in the world, 'Sfoot do thou stab me, and thou hast a mind to it, or bid me stab myself, is this thy friend? dost thou love Lodouico?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: With my heart I protest Sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: 'sheart, he lies in his throat that does not; and whence comest thou wag, ha?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: Even new arrived from Padua Sir to see fashions.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, thou art welcome; and for thy fashions, thou shalt first drink and wench it: to which end we will carouse a little, some six or seven miles hence, and every man carry his wench.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: But where shall we have them Captain?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Have them Lieutenant? if we have them not, my Valentine shall be one, and she shall take a neighbour or two with her to see their nursed childes or so; we will want for no wenches I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: But who comes here?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: O it is my Barber.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'sblood how thy trades men haunt thee.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Alas they that live by men, must haunt them ,

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.l: God save you Sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: How now Cutberd, what news out of Barbary?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.l: Sir, I would borrow a word with you in private.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Be brief then Cutbeard, thou lookest lean methinks , I think thou art newly married.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.l: I am indeed Sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: I thought so, keep on thy hat man, it will be the less perceived, what, is not my Taylor and you friends yet? I will have you friends that is certain, I will maintain you both else.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.l: I know no enmity betwixt us Sir, you know Captain I come about another matter.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why but Cutbeard, are not you neighbours? your trades Cousin german, the Taylor and the Barber? does not the Taylor sow? dost not thou Barber reap? and do they not both band themselves against the common enemy of mankind, the louse? are you not both honest men alike? is not he an arrant knave? you next door to a knave, because next door to him?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.l: Alas Sir, all this is to no purpose, there are certain odd crowns betwixt us you know.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: True Cutbeard, wilt thou lend me as many more to make them even Boy?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.l: Faith Sir, they have hung long enough a conscience.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Cut them down then Cutbeard, it belongs to thy profession if they hang too long.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.l: Well Sir if this be all, I will come by them as I can, and you had any honesty.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: 'sblood honesty you knave? do you tax any Gentleman in this company for his honesty?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.l: Blame me not sir, I am undone by him, and yet I am still of as good credit in my Parish as he too.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: 'sblood Rascal, as good credit as I?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay prithee Captain forbear.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Good Captain be gone.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Let me alone;I will not strike him by this hand, why hark ye Rogue: put your credit in balance with mine? dost thou keep this company? here is Seignior Lodouico, one of the Clarissimi, a man of worship: here is a Gentleman of Padua, a man of rare parts, an excellent scholar, a fine Ciceronian.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.l: Well sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: And here is my Lieutenant, I hope thou knowest the Worshipful man his father with the blew beard, and all these are my companions; and dare you a barbarous slave, a squirting companion, compare with me? but here is the point; now behold and see: Seignior Giouenelle, lend me four or five pounds, let it be five pounds, if you have so much about you.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: Here is my purse sir, I think there be just so much in it.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Very good, now Cutbeard, are you a slanderous cut-throat or no? will thy credit do this now? without scrip or scroll. But thou wilt think this is done for a colour now; do you not lend it me simply?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: What a question is that?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: For how long?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: At your pleasure Captain.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why so, here you poling Rascal, here is two crowns out of this money: now I hope wilt believe it is mine, now the property is altered.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.l: Why you might have done this before then.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: No Cutbeard, I have been burned in the hand for that, I will pay never a knave of ye all money, but in the presence of such honest Gentleman that can witness it; of my conscience I have paid it thee half a dozen times; go to sir be gone.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.l: Fare ye well sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Thank you Seignior Giouenelle, though you are sure of this money again at my hands, yet take heed how this same Lodouico get it from you, he is a great sharker; but thou hast no more money about thee hast thou?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: Not a do it, by this candle.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: All the better, for he would cheat thee on it, if thou hadst ever so much, therefore when thou comest to Padua, ply thy book and take good courses, and it is not this again shall serve thy turn at my hands, I swear to thee.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: Thank you good Captain.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Seignior Lodouico, adieu.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Not so sir, we will not part yet, a carouse or two methinks is very necessary betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: With all my heart Boy, into the Emperors head here.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Say Sir, have you played the man and housed the Captain?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I have housed and lodged him in the Emperors head Tavern, and there I have left him glorified with his two gulls, so that presume of what thou wilt at his house, for he is out of the way by this time both ways.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: It is very well handled sir, and presume you and; your friend my master Aurelio of what may satisfy you at your uncles, for he is now going out of the way, and out of himself also: I have so besmeared him with a chimney sweepers resemblance, as never was poor Snail, whose counterfeit he triumphs in, never thinking I have daubed his face sufficient, but is at his glass as curiously busied to beautify his face (for as of Moors so of chimney sweepers) the blackest is most beautiful as any Lady to paint her lips.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Thou art a notable villain.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I am the fitter for your employment Sir: stand close I beseech you, and; when I bring him into the streets, encounter and bait him in stead of Snail, but in any case let none else know it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Not for the world.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: If you should tell it to one, so you charge him to say nothing, it were nothing, and so if one by one to it play holy water frog with twenty, you know any secret is kept sufficiently; and in this, we shall have the better sport at a Bear baiting, fare ye well Sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Seignior Lodouico good even to you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The like to Seignior Lorenzo, and hark you Sir, I must be bound with my uncle and tell you a pleasant secrete of him, so in no sort you will utter it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: In no sort as I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why Sir he is to walk the streets presently in the likeness of Snail the chimney sweeper, and with his cry.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: What is he Sir? to what end I beseech you Sir will he disfigure himself so?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: i'faith Sir I take it for some matter of policy, that concerns town government.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Town bull government, do you not mean so Sir?

sp.speaker: Lon.
sp.l: O no Sir, but for the general business of the City I take it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Well sir well we will not examine it too far , but guess at it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So sir when he comes forth do you take one corner to encounter him as I will do another, and taking him for Snail, imagine he went about stealing of City venison, though he do not, and make what sport you think good with him, always provided it be cleanly, and that he may still think he goes invisible.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I warrant ye Seignior Loduico, and thank you heartily for this good cause of our honest recreation.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Scarce honest neither sir, but much good do it you, as it is,

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: O that my son, your friend Aurelio, were here to help to candy this jest a little.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Alas sir, his sick stomach can abide no sweet meats, he is all for aye me, we will make the Jest relish well enough I warrant you: Lorenzo my uncle an old Senator, one that has read Marcus Auerlius, Gesta Romanorum, the Mirror of Magistrates, etcetera to be led by the nose like a blind Bear that has read nothing. Let my man read how he deserves to be baited.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: It is a pretty wonder i'faith Seignior Lodouico.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'slife, it were a good deed, to get boys to pin cards at his back, hang squibs at his tail, ring him through the town with basins, besnowball him with rotten eggs, and make him ashamed of the Commission before he seal it.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: What says Seignior Lodouico, I beseech you sir? methinks his pleasant disposition should intend some waggery.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: I will tell you Seignior Gasparo, but in any case you must say nothing.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: In no case will I say anything sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Then this is the case: Seignior Lorenzo (your probable father in law) in the case of Snail the chimney sweeper, will straight tread the streets for his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: For his pleasure?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: For his pleasure sir, say it be so, wonder not, but jest at it, consider what pleasure the world says he is most given to, and help bait him hereafter, but in any case cleanly, and say nothing.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: O monstrous, I conceive you, my father in law, will his daughter have his tricks think you?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Faith for that you must even take fortune de la pace, kiss the Pox, and be patient like your other neighbours. So, here stand I, chose you another place.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: O me, what if a man should call him to sweep a chimney in earnest, what would he do? I will put him to it a my credit, and here will I stand.

body.stage: Enter Lorenzo with his glasse in his hand, and Angelo with a pot of painting.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How now sir, are you well yet think you?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A little more here good Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Very well sir, you shall have enough.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: It will be the most perfect disguise that ever was imitated.

sp.speaker: Ang.
Lor.
sp.l: Yet a little more here Angelo, and then master Painter let Michael Angelo himself amend thee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: For a perfect natural face, I care not if all the world explain it.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: So now take this glass, and give me my furniture, and have at your smoky chimney.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Have at your smoky chimney Mistress Franke here sir take up your occupation, and down with Snail for a chimney sweeper.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Away, see if the coast be clear.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Take good view, look about to the doors and windows.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Not a dog at a door, not a cat at a window.
Appear in your likeness, and not with your quality.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Chimney sweep; work for chimney sweep, wilt do sirrah ?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Admirably.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Does my suit become me?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Become you sir? would to heaven mistress Franke could bring you to the wearing of it always.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I will forth i'faith then; Maids in your smocks, set open your locks,
sp.l: Down , down, down:
Let Chimney sweeper in:
And he will sweep your chimneys clean,
Hey derry, derry, down.
How dost like my cry, ha?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Out of all cry, I forbid Snail himself to creep beyond you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: As God help, I begin to be proud on it: Chimney sweep.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Gods pity, who comes yonder?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: My nephew Lodowicke; Gods me, I will start back again.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay there is no starting now, he will see you go into your house then; fall into your note; stand to Snails person and I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Chimney sweep.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How now Snail, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Thank your good worship.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Methinks thy song is more hearty then it was wont to be, and thou lookest much better.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Thank God and good friends sir; and a merry heart that prolongs life. Chimney sweep.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay good Snail, let us talk a little, you know Rose mine uncle Lorenzoes maid Snail!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That I do well sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: She complains of you Snail, and says, you are the bawdiest old knave in venery.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Alas sir, she wrongs me: I am not fed thereafter, let her look for that commendation in her richer customers.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Who are they Snail? I hope you do not mean mine uncle her Master;he is mine uncle and I love him well, and I know the old lickspiggot will be nibbling a little when he can come to it: but I must needs say he will do no hurt, he is as gentle as an Adder that has his teeth taken out.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: You are a merry Gentleman sir; and I have hasty labour in hand, I must crave pardon.
Chimney sweep.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.l: What old Snail? how dost thou and thy chimneys?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Marry sir I was asking him questions about one of them.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.l: What Seignior Lodouico? what one is that I pray?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Mine uncle Lorenzo maid Rose sir, and he will needs persuade me, her old master keeps her for his own saddle.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: Her old master? I dare swear they wrong him that say so; his very age would make him ashamed to be overtaken with those goatish licences.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: True sir, and his great authority in the City, that should whip such unseasonable lechers about the walls of it.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: Why, you are in the right sir, and now you talk of your uncle, I heard say Captain Quintiliano cheated him yesterday of five pounds, as he did a young Gentleman of Padua this morning of as much more.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Faith sir he drew such a kind of tooth from him indeed .

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: Is it possible he should be so wrought upon by him? Now certain I have ever held him a most wise Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: An arrant Rook by this light; a capable cheating stock; a man may carry him up and down by the ears like a pipkin.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.l: But do you think he will let the Captain pass so?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Why alas, what should he do to him sir? the pasture is so bare with him, that a goose cannot graze upon it .

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: Marry sir then would I watch him a time when he were abroad, and take out my pennyworths of his wife, if he drew a tooth from me, I would draw another from her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Well, God be with your worships: chimney sweeper, I thought I should never have been rid of them,
sp.l: Chimney sweep.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: What old Snail, dost thou cry chimney sweep still? why they say thou art turned mighty rich of late.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I would they said true sir?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Yes by the mass, by the same token, that those riches make thy old name for venery increase upon thee.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Foolish tales sir, foolish tales.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.p: Yes by the mass, Snail, but they be told for such certain tales, that if thou hast a daughter to marry with ten thousand crowns, I would see her pithole, afore I would deal with her, for fear she should trot through her fathers trumperies.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Alas sir your worship knows, I have neither daughter nor riches, Idle talk sir, Idle talk: chimney sweep.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Nay stay Snail, and come into my house, thou shalt earn some money of me, I have a chimney to sweep for thee.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I thank your worship, I will wait upon you next morning early sir: but now I have promised to sweep another man's chimney in truth.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: But good Snail take mine in the way.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: What does he cry chimney sweep, and refuse to sweep them ?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: No master, alas you know I live by it, and now I cry as I go to work that I have promised, that I may get more against other times: what would ye have me do trot?

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.l: Alas poor Snail; farewell good farewell.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Lord keep your good worship. ~~ And a very vengeance, I beseech the black father of vengeance.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Poor uncle, he begins to be melancholy, has lost his song among us

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Was never such man touched with such oversight?

sp.speaker: Hon:
sp.p: Bear with age, Seignior Gasparo, bear with age, and let us all tender his credit as we have vowed, and be silent; he little thought to have been thus betrayed as he is; and where secrecy is assured, it bears with many bad actions in the very best I can tell you, and so good Seignior Lodouico adieu, and I heartily thank you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Adieu good Seignior Honorio.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Adieu to you likewise sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Likewise to you sir. Alas poor uncle, I have monstrously abused him; and yet marvelous worthy, for he disparageth the whole blood of us; and I wish all such old sheep-biters might always dip their fingers in such sauce to their mutton; but thus will he presently be safe; for by this he is near his sweet hearts house, where he is like to be entertained with worse cheer than we made him. Quintilliano is now carousing in the Emperors head, while his own head buds horns to carouse in; and in the mean time will my amorous friend and I, make both their absences shoeing horns to draw on the presence of Aemilia

body.stage: Enter Lorenzo and Angelo. Francisco aboue.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What says your worship now? Do you not walk invisible, all your ancient acquaintance, your own nephew to talk with you and never discover you?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: But Angelo, a villainous fear shook me the whilst I swear, for still I was afraid my tongue would have liked away the soot of my face, and bewrayed me; but Snail, hitherto thy rusty shell has protected me: persevere till I have yonder house a my head, hold in thy horns, till they look out of Quintilleanoes forehead: for an old man to make a young man cuckold, is one of Hercules labours.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: That was the cleansing of other men's stables.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: To make youth rampant in age, and age passant in youth, to take a man down at his own weapon; to call back time in one, and thrust him headlong upon another.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Now your worship is Oracle to your own miracles; how you shine in this smoky cloud? which you make the golden net to embrace Venus, you have past the pikes i'faith, and all the Jails of the love god swarm in yonder house, to salute your recovery.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well Angelo, I tell thee, now we are past the danger, I would not for forty crowns but have heard, what I have heard.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: True sir, now you know what the world thinks on you, it is not possible for a great man, that shines always in his greatness, to know himself ; but O twice young Leander, see where your Hero stands with torch of her beauty to direct you to her tower, advance your sweet note and; upon her.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Chimney sweep, work for chimney sweep.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Come in chimney sweeper.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: O Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Why now sir thine Angelo is your good Angel; enter and prosper, and when you are in the midst of your happiness, think of him that preferred you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Angelo, give him not too much time with me, for fear of the worst, but go presently to the back gate, and use my husbands knock, then will I presently thrust him into my cole-house: and there shall the old flesh-monger fast for his iniquity.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well said mine own Franke i'faith, we shall trim him betwixt us, I for the most slovenly case in the town; she, for the most sluttish place in the house: Never was old horse-man so notoriously ridden; well, I will presently knock him into the cole-house, and then haste to Lodouico, to know when he shall be released.

body.stage: Enter Lodouico with a ladder of ropes, Aurelio, milia aboue.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Here is thy ladder, and there is thy gallows, thy Mistress is thy hangman, and must take thee down: This is the Tarrasse where thy sweet heart tarries; what wouldst thou call it in rhyme?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Celestial sphere, wherein more beauty shines.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Room for a passion.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Then on Dardanian Ida, where the pride Of heavens selected beauties strived for prize.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay you shall know, we have watered our houses in Helicon. I cannot abide this talking and undoing Poetry, leave your mellifluous numbers: yonder is a sight will steal all reason from your rhyme I can tell you; down of your knees you slave, adore.
