Now let us hear you invocate, O the supple hams of a lover, go to, do not, stand up close, for she must not see you yet, though she know you are here.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Lodowicke Cozen

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Who calls Lodowicke?

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: What tempest hath cast you on this solitary shore? Is the party come?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: The party? now a plague of your modesty, are your lips too nice to name Aurelio?

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Well, is he come then?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He, which he? 'Sfoot name your man with a mischief to you, I understand you not.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Was there ever such a wild-brain? Aurelio.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Aurelio? Lord how loath you are to let any sound of him come out of you, you hold him so dear within, I will present her with a sight, will startle her nicety a little better; hold you, fasten the end of this ladder I pray.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Now Iesus bless us, why cousin, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Go to you spirit of a feather, be not so soft hearted, leave your nicety, or by this hemp I will so hamper thy affections in the halter of thy lovers absence, making it up in a gordian knot of forgetfulness, that no Alexander of thy allurements, with all the swords of thy sweet words, shall ever cut in pieces.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Lord, how you roll in your rope-ripe terms.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Go to, tell me, will you fasten the ladder or no?

sp.speaker: m.
sp.p: I know not what I should say to ye: I will fasten it, so only yourself will come up.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Only myself will come up then.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Nay sweet Cuz, swear it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: If I should swear thou wouldst curse me: take my word in a halters name, and make the ladder as fast to the Tarrasse, as thou wouldst be to Aurelio.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Nay see if he do not make me give over again?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Was there ever such a blew kitling? fasten it now, or by heaven thou dost lose me forever .

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Well sir, remember your word; I will fasten it, but i'faith Cuz, is not the Gentleman, and his parting choler parted yet?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: i'faith with much ado:

sp.speaker: m.
sp.p: Nay, nay, choose him; I shall live, if they be not: and if I live till his choler kill me, I shall live till he leave loving me, and that will be a good while first.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Lord, Lord, who has informed you of such amorous fervency in him: are you so confident in his kindness?

sp.speaker: m.
sp.p: Nay by my troth, it is but a careless confidency neither, which always last longer then that which is timorous: well Cuz, here I have fastened it for your pleasure; but alas, the fear of my fathers coming does so distract me that I scarce know what I do or say.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Your father? dost think we would venture all this preparation, and not make him safe?

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: But are you sure he is safe?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Am I sure this is Aurelio? look upon him wench, is it not thy love? thy life? come sir, mount.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: O cousin Lodowicke, do you thus cousin and betray me?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Cuz, Cuz, thou hast acted thy dissembling part long enough, in the most modest judgment, and passing naturally: give over with thy credit then, unmask thy love , let her appear in her native simplicity, strive to conceal her no longer from thy love, for I must needs tell thee he knows all.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: What does he know?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Why all that thou toldest me, that thou lovest him more than he can love thee, that thou hast set up thy resolution, in despite of friends or foes, weals or woes, to let him possess thee wholly, and that thou didst woo me to bring him hither to thee: All this he knows; that it was thy device to prepare this ladder, and in a word, all the speech that past betwixt thee and me he knows, I told him every word truly and faithfully Gods my Judge.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Now was there ever such an immodest creature?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Via, with all vain modesty, leave this colouring, and strip thy love stark naked, this time is too precious to spend vainly; mount I say.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Model of heavenly beauty.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'swounds, wilt thou melt into rhyme on the the other side? shall we have lines? change thy style for a ladder, this will bring thee to Parnassus, up I say.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Unworthy I to the furthest step to that felicity that shines in her.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: O purblind affection, I have seen a fellow, to a worse end ascend a ladder with a better will, and yet this is in the way of marriage, and they say, marriage and hanging have both one constellation. To approve the which old saying, see if a new ladder make them not agree.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Peace, somebody comes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: That you heard, was but a mouse, so boy I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O sacred goddess, whatsoever thou art
That in mere pity to preserve a soul
From undeserved destruction, hast vouchsafed
To take AEmiliaes shape.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: What a poetical sheep is this? 'slife, will you stand riming there upon a stage, to be an eye-mark to all that pass? is there not a chamber by? withdraw I say for shame, have you no shame in you? here will come somebody presently I lay my life on it.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Dear mistress, to avoid that likely danger,
Vouchsafe me only private conference,
And it is the fulness of my present hopes.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Aurelio, Occasion is bald, take her by the forelock; so, so. In Hymens name get you together, here will I stand Sentinel. This is the back gate to Honorios house, which shall be Aurelios, if God give him grace to weep for his fathers death in time. And in this garden, if I could see the chaste Lucresse, or the affable mistress Temperance, I might (thus wrapped in my cloak) steal a little courtship through the chink of a pale. But indeed I think it safer to sit closer, and so to cloud the sum of my visnomy, that no eye discern it.
sp.stage: He sits downe, and muffles himselfe in his cloake.
sp.p: So be it, that is my resolution. Now to my contemplation, this is no Panderism, is it? No, for there is neither money nor credit proposed or expected, and besides there is no unlawful act intended, no not this same lasciua action animi : I think for his part, much less hers: go to, let me do my kinswoman, and her sex right, sit at rest with me then reputation, and conscience, fall asleep with the world, but this same idle attendance is the spite of it, Idleness is accounted with other men a sin, to me it is a penance, I was begot in a stirring season, for now hath my soul a thousand fancies in an instant, as what wench dreams on when she lies on her back, when one hen lays an egg and another sits it, whether that hen shall mother that chicken? If my bull leap your cow, is not the calf yours? yes no doubt, for AEdificium cedit solo says the Lawyer: and then to close all comes in a sentence, Non omnia possumus omnes: for some are borne to riches, others to verses, some to be bachelors, others to be cuckolds, some to get crowns, and others to spend them , some to get children, and others to keep them : and all this is but idleness, would to God I had some scurvy poem about me to laugh at,
sp.l: but mark, yonder is a motion to be seen.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.l: Yonder he sits ysaith, well done true love, good Seignior Leonoro, he keeps promise the best, he does not see me yet.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: It is the stayed Madam Temperance, a pretty pinnace she has been in her days, and in her nights too, for her burthen, and reasonable good under sail, and see she hath discovered a sail, see, see, she hales him in, ha? it is this way to the rewards, slight it is this way: I hope the bawd knows not me, and yet I know not, she may be a witch, for a whore she was before I knew her, a bawd I have known her any time this dozen years, the next step to honour then is a witch, because of Nature, for where the whore ends, the bawd begins, and the corruption of a bawd, is the generation of a witch. And holds opinion, that a witch turns to a wild Cat, as an old Ostler turns to an ambling nag.

body.stage: Enter Leonoro muffled in his cloake with Lyonell.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: This is the back gate, where Temperance should meet me at this hour.

sp.speaker: Lyon.
sp.l: I wonder she sails, for I see her not.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Why sits that fellow there trow? come let us hover hereabouts it will not be long ere we encounter.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: So, now this riddle is expounded, this bawd took me for this adventurer whom (twenty to one) she attended, to waft him into chamber, what a beast was I, not to apprehend this advantage, thus muffled as I am, she could not have perceived me till I had been in, And I might safely have staid a while without endangering my lovers:
sp.stage: Enter Temperance stealing along the stage.
sp.l: 'Slight she takes me still for her first man.

sp.speaker: Tem.
sp.l: Come, come, gingerly for Gods sake, gingerly.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: See Lyonell, yet she is not come, and the privy attendant is gone.

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: I wonder what it was.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I fear me some other client of hers, whom she prefers before me, come, we must not linger here too long together, we will enter on this backside, to the Emperors head, where we will stay a little, and then make the last trial of this bawds honesty.

body.stage: Enter Quintiliano, Giouenelli, and Fannio in their doublet and hose.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Come Ancient, let us leave our company a little, and air ourselves in this backside. ~~ Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A friend.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: The word.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: God save you Captain Quintiliano.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Shoot him Ancient, a spy, the word is the Emperors head, and thither you shall go sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Pardon me good Captain.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Come, be not retrograde to our desires.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I attend a friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Thou hast attended him already, I am witness to it, deny it if he dare, whatsoever he be, and he shall attend thee another while, and he will: Thou art as good a man as he, and he be the Duke himself, for a Clarissimo; entertain him Ancient, bid the Clarissimo welcome, I will call a drawer, and we will have some wine in this Arbor.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: You are very welcome Seignior Clarissimo, desire you more acquaintance sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: My name is Leonoro sir, and; indeed I scarce know you.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.p: No sir, and you know me, you must know as much as I know, for Scientia and Scientificus is all one; but that is all one, in truth sir, you shall not spend a penny here, I had money, I thank God even now, and peradventure shall have again ever we part, I have sent to a friend of mine.

body.stage: Enter Quintilliano and a drawer with a cup of wine a towell.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Here honourable Clarissimo, I drink to thee.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thank you good Captain.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, winesucker, what have you filled us here, balderdash? Taste Leonoro.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Methinks it is sack.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Let us taste sir, it is claret, but it has been fetched again with Aqua-vitae.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: 'Slight methinks it has taken salt water, who drew this wine you rogue?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: My fellow Sam drew it sir, the wine is a good neat wine, but you love a pleasanter grape, I will fit your palate sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Is this thy boy Leonoro?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: For fault of a better sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Afore heaven it is a sweet faced child, methinks he should show well in woman's attire: and he took her by the lily white hand, and he laid her upon a bed. I will help thee to three crowns a week for him, and she can act well. Hast ever practised my pretty

sp.speaker: Lyo.
sp.l: No, nor never mean sir.

sp.speaker: Gio.
sp.l: Mean sir? no marry Captain, there will never be mean in his practise I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: O finely taken; Sirrah, Clarissimo, this fellow was an arrant Ass this fore noon, afore he came to be an Ancient.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But where is your Lieutenant Captain?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: 'swounds man, he is turned swaggerer.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Swaggerer by this light he; and is in the next room writing a challenge to this tall Gentleman my Ancient here.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What, mutinous in your own company?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: 'Sfoot man, who can bridle the asses valour?

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: 'sblood and any man think to bridle me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But what was the quarrel?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why sir, because I entertained this Gentleman for my Ancient, (being my dear friend and an excellent scholar) he takes pepper in the nose and sneezes it out upon my Ancient; now sir he being of an uncoal-carrying spirit) falls foul on him, calls him gull openly; and ever since I am fain to drink with them in two rooms, dare not let them come together for my life, but with pen and ink-horns, and so my Lieutenant is in the next chamber casting cold Ink upon thee.
sp.l: flame of his courage, to keep him from the blot of cowardice, see where he comes with his challenge: good Clarissimo hold my Ancient.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Good Ancient, forbear in a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Revenge noble Lieutenant, hast thou done it?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: 'Slight I think I have peppered him, but it was his own seeking you know.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: That is certain.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: 'swounds my seeking sir?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Hold him Leonoro; and if it be possible, persuade him to hear the challenge from the enemies own mouth.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I will undertake he shall Captain: Good Ancient let me entreat you.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: Well sir, because you are a stranger to me, you shall do more with me.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thank you good ancient.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Read fiery Lieutenant, read boy, legibly.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Here it is sir: Seignior Giouenelli, it is not ignorant unto you, that even now you crossed me over the cocks-comb.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: I did so sir: I will not deny it I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Good Ancient peace.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: And that openly, or else it would never have grieved me.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: That openly was all indeed.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: And moreover, very unreverently to call me gull, and ass to my face: And therefore, though I held it good discretion in me to wink at the blow, not seeing to take notice of it.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Good discretion in deed.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Yet know that I will have satisfaction from you.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: Well sir, and you shall.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Nay good Ancient hear him.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: And desire you to send me word, whether you will maintain it or no, hoping that you will not offer that discourtesy to do me wrong, and stand to it when you have done.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: That were foul indeed.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: And as for the words, in that you called me gull, and Ass to my face, resolve me by letter (for I do not think fit we should meet) first whether you spake any such words or no: and secondly by whom you meant them . And if by me (as I think you durst not) confess you are sorry for them : and if I have offended you, I heartily ask you forgiveness. And so farewell.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Afore heaven Ancient, this would have tickled you, but good and thou beest a right let us make them friends, and drink to one another: 'Sfoot, we have no wine here methinks , where is this Aperner?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.l: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Have you mended your hand sir.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: Aye Captain, and if this please not your taste, either you or I cannot taste a cup of wine.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Sounds you are very saucy sir, here Lieutenant, drink to thy Ancient, and void mutinies with your officer, marshall law is dangerous.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Is he content I should drink to him?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: He is I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Why then Ancient good luck to ye.

sp.speaker: Giou.
sp.l: Let come Lieutenant, I pledge you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why so, now my company is cured again, afore it was wounded. Come honourable let us retire to our strength, taste a fresh carouse or two, and then march home with Music. Tapster, call us in some Music.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.l: I will sir.

body.stage: Enter Quintiliano, Leonoro, Innocentio, Lionello, Fannio, with Musicke.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Strike up Scrapers, honourable Clarissimo, and thy sweet Adonis, adieu, remember our device at the show soon .

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: I will not fail Captain, farewell to ye both: come now let us try the truth of Madam Temperance, and see if she attend us .

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: I hope by this time she remembers her promise sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: How now Lieutenant, where is my Ancient?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Marry Captain you have left him casting the reckoning in the chimney.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why then his purse and his stomach will be empty together, and so I cashier him; let the scholar report at Padua, that Venice has other manner of learning belongs to it: what does his Continuum and Contiguum here? let them go to the Ink pot and beware of the wine pot.
sp.l: Fill red cheeked Bacchus, let the Burdex grape
la voltos Skip like la voltos in their swelling veins.
Te dan, dan tidle, te dan the dan tidle diddle, etcetera.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: O God Captain that I could dance so.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: He took her by (strike up fiddlers) the lily white hand and he laid her upon the bed. O what a spirit have I now? I long to meet a Sergeant in this humour, I would but have one whiff at one of these same pewter buttoned shoulder-clappers, to try whether this chopping knife or their pestles were the better weapons. Here is a blade Boy, it was the old Dukes first predecessors; I will tell thee what Lieutenant, this sword has dubbed more Knights than thy knife has opened Oysters.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Is it possible Captain, and methinks it stands a little.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: No matter for that, your best metalled blades will stand soonest: so, now we have attained our Mansion house. At which I will sing a verse shall break the doors. O noble Hercules, let no Stygian lake. Te dan dan tidle, te dan de dan tidle diddle etcetera Farewell scrapers, your reward now shall be that I will not cut your strings nor break your fiddles, via away.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Come Captain, let us enter, I long to see my Mistress, I warrant she is a heavy Gentlewoman for your absence.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: 'Sfoot she is an Ass, honour woos me, preferment calls me, and I must lie pampered in a wenches lap, because she dotes on me. Honour says no, Lieutenant. Pugna pro patria, we must to it i'faith and seek our portion amongst the scratched faces.

sp.speaker: Lorenzo within.
sp.l: Mistress, Mistress, is he gone?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Who is that calls there?

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: I heard nobody .

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: No? there was one called Mistress: I say who called Mistress, 'sblood I hope I am not drunk.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.l: In truth sir I heard nobody .

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: I tell thee I smelt a voice here in my entry, 'Sfoot I will make it smell worse and cheer it again .

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: O me, he will draw upon his own shadow in this humour, if it take the wall of him. Follow him Fannio, look he do no harm for God sake.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Name of God, what is there to do ?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Good Captain do not hurt me.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Sounds is hell broke loose? why Snail, though you can sing songs and do things Snail, I must not allow ye to creep into my wives cole-house, what Snail, into my withdrawing chamber?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I beseech your Worship hear me speak .

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: O Snail, this is a hard case; no room serve your turn, but my wives cole-house, and her other house of office annexed to it? a privy place for herself , and me sometimes, and will you use it being a stranger? 'Slight how comes this about? up sirrah and call your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A plague of all disguises.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Alas poor Snail, what didst thou make here?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I protest sir for no harm, my Mistress called me in to sweep her chimney, and because I did it not to her mind, she made me do penance in her cole-house.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Search him Captain and see, if he have stolen nothing.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Kill me, hang me, if I have.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Yes Snail, and besides I hear complaints of you, you are an old luxurious hummerer about wenches Snail, does this become your gravity sir? Lieutenant, fetch me a coal sack, I will put him in it and hang him up for a sign.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I beseech your Worship be good to me.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Good Captain pardon him, since he has done nothing but swept your chimney worse than my Mistress would have it swept, he will do it better another time.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Well Snail, at this Gentleman's request, (to whom I can deny nothing) I release you for this once, but let me take you no more thus I advise you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Not while I live good Captain.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Hence, trudge you drudge, go away.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A plague of all disguises.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.l: I have looked about all the house for my Mistress sir, but I cannot find her.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Go then, look all about the town for her too; come in Lieutenant, let us repose a little after our liquor.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Dear life, be resolute, that no respect
Heighted above the compass of your love,
Depress the equal comforts it retains;
For since it finds a firm consent in both,
And both our births and years agree so well,
If both our aged parents should refuse,
For any common object of the world,
To give their hands to ours, let us resolve
To live together like our lives and souls.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: I am resolved my love; and yet alas,
So much affection to my fathers will
Consorts the true desires I bear to you,
That I would have no spark of our love seen,
Till his consent be asked, and so your fathers.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: So runs the mutual current of my wish,
And with such staid and circumspect respects,
We may so serve and govern our desires,
That till fit observation of our fathers,
Prefer the motion to them; we may love
Without their knowledge and the skill of any,
Save only of my true friend Lodowicke.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: I wonder where he is.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Not far I know,
For in some place, he watcheth to prevent
The feared danger of your fathers presence.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Sounds stay for the love of your honour sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A plague of all disguises Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What reason have you to curse them? has not one of them kept you safe from the shame of the world, as much as a poor disguise might do; but when your ridiculous fears will cast it off, even while it is on, so running through the streets, that they rise all in an uproar after you: alas what is the poor disguise to blame sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well then fortune is to blame, or something ; come as thou didst help to daub me, help to cleanse me, I prithee.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Let alone a while sir for Gods sake, I will go see whether the Captain be gone from home or no.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Out upon that course Angelo; I am frighted out of it, come enter my house, enter.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What, will you enter your house sir afore you know who is in it: keep yourself close, and let me first enter and discover.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I know there is nobody .

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You cannot know it sir, I heard even now that divers of the Senate were determined to come and sit in Counsel there.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: A tale, a very tale Angelo, enter for the love of heaven, enter and unsmother me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What shall I do? my poor Master is bewrayed, O that same faithless Lodowicke, that could drown the swaggering Captain no better in his drunkenness; alas how should I salve this?

body.stage: Enter Lorenzo and after him Angelo.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: How now? whom do I see? my daughter and a younker together? passion of death, hell and damnation, what lecherous capricorn reigns this unhappy day? old and young in a predicament? O fie of filthy sin and concupiscence, I will conceal my rage a while that it may break forth in fury; I will shift me presently Angelo, and go fetch the Provost.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: O unspeakable madness, will you forever dishonour your daughter, and in her yourself sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Talk not to me, out upon this abominable concupiscence, the pride of the flesh, this witchcraft of the Devil: talk not to me, justice cries out on it in the streets, and I will see it punished, come good Angelo to help to shift me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will follow you Sir instantly; Master, Master.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Angelo? what news?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Miserable Master, cast down your ladder, and come down instantly.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Alas, why, Angelo is my father coming.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Let us not talk but come down I say.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Dear life, farewell, we will shortly meet again,
So parts the dying body from the soul;
As I depart from my Aemilia.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: So enter frighted souls to the low world,
As my poor spirit upon this sudden doubt,
What may succeed this danger.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Come away, you will be whipped anon for your amorosity, haste for shame haste , etcetera.

sp.speaker: m.
sp.l: Once more and ever, fare my dear life well.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Leave you amorous conges and; get you in Dame; sir you and I will talk as it were betwixt the pales, now, get you and shift you of this suit presently.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Shift me Angelo? why man?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Ask me no questions, but go home and shift you presently, and when I have done a little business here within, I will come and tell you my device: there hath more chanced than you are aware of, and then I can stand to tell you; away therefore presently go home and shift you.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Very good sir, I will be ruled by you, and after learn the mysteries.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Now will I let the little squire shift and cleanse himself without me, that he may be longer about fetching the Provost, and in the mean time will I take my Masters suit (of which the little squire took note) and put it on my sweet heart Francischina, who shall presently come and supply my Masters place, with his Mistress; for the little squire amazed with his late affrights and this sudden offenceful spectacle of his daughter, took no certain note who it was that accosted her; for if he had, he would have blamed me for my Master, only the colour of his garment sticks in his fancy, which when he shall still see where he left it, he will still imagine the same person wears it, and thus shall his daughters honour and my Masters be preserved with the finest sugar of invention. And when the little squire discovers my sweet heart, she shall swear, she so disguised herself, to follow him, for her love to him; ha, ha ha. O the wit of man when it has the wind of a woman.

body.stage: Enter Lodouico and Lucretia, with Rapiers fighting.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Hold hold, I prithee hold; I yield my rapier,
Let my submission, my presumption salve.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Ignoble Lodowicke, should I take thy life,
It were amends too little for the wrong.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: O the precious heavens:
How was I gulled? bawd, hide thyself for shame.
And henceforth have an eye before thy fingers.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Well do not jest it out, for I protest
If this disguise, which my inhuman fate
Puts on my proper sex, be by thy means
Seen through, by any other than thyself ,
The quarrel twixt us shall be more than mortal.
And thy dishonour to a friendless stranger
(Exiled his native country, to remain
Thrall to the mercy of such unknown maids
As fortune makes the rulers of my life)
Shall spread itself beyond my misery,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Nay, mix not cause of mirth with passion,
Do me the grace to unfold thy name and state,
And tell me what my whole estate may do,
To salve this wrong unwittingly I did thee?
And set the plaintiff thoughts of thy hard fate
In such peace, as my friendship may procure:
And if I fail thee, let Jove fail my soul,
When most this earth makes it need help of heaven.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: In the more than temper my late rage
And show your virtues perfectly derived
From the Venetian nobles; for my name
It is Lucretio which to fit this habit
I turned Lucretia: the rest that rests
To be related of my true estate,
I will tell some other time: lest now your presence
Might dumbly tell it (if it should be scene)
To all the world, or else make it suspect
My female life of lightness: then with thanks
And vow of all true friendship, for the amends
Your kindness makes me, take your sword again,
And with it while I live the power of mine
In any honoured use shall command.
Then till we meet, and may laugh at this error,
I will once more try the free peace of my chamber.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Do so sweet friend: a plague of Gingerly?
Where is that stale and fulsome Gingerly,
She brought me to a fury, I will be sworn
Rather than man or woman: a flat beating:
I found her supposed mistress fast asleep,
Put her to the touchstone, and she prove a man.
He waked, and with a more than manly spirit
Flew in my face, and gave me such a dash
In steed of kissing, of these licorice lips
That still my teeth within them bled I swear
Gingerly, Gingerly a plague a you.
But now how does my lovers on the Tarrasse?

body.stage: Enter Aurelio with Angelo, shifting his Apparell.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Hold take my doublet too, my hat and all, and quickly hie thee to thy sweet.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: 'swounds, see sir see, your proper Sentinel, that when you needed him, gave you a slip.

sp.speaker: Anr.
sp.l: Friend Lodouico, by my life, well welcome to this my fathers backside.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Well sir, well, I would I had kissed almost your fathers backside so I had never known it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: On my life he faints extremely, he left you even now to purchase him the amorous interview of your fair cuz Lucretia that lies here .

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Gods me, sweet friend, wouldst thou use such a slight to anyone that lay within my walk? who was thy mean to her?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I lay my life, tame madam Temperance, the notorious Pander.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: 'Sfoot friend, what a notorious oversight was that and what a violent injury unto thy friend?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: A plague upon you both, you scurvy hind, have you no gull but me to whet your wit upon ?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: My friend a privy lover? I would have sworn
Love might spend all his shafts at butterflies
As well as at his bosom.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: It was your fault then,
For I have noted a most faithful league
Betwixt him and his barber now of late,
And all the world may see, he does not leave
One hair on his smooth chin, as who should say,
His hapless love was gone against the hair.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: 'sblood if; these rogues knew how I was deceived,
They would flout me into motley, by this light.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well sir, I ever thought you had the best wit
Of any man in Venice next mine own,
But now I will lay the bucklers at your feet,

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: A pox upon thee, tame your bald hewed tongue,
Or by the Lord of heaven I will pull it out.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O my sweet friend, come I will know more of this,
And tell thee all our fortune, hence good Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: O, if this man had patience to his brain,
A man might load him till he smart again.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Patience worthy friend, he knows you love him for his knavish wit.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Thou shalt not stay sweet Temperance, tell us the manner of our war and we will leave thee presently.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.p: Why that perl's man Lodowicke, according to your appointment was jump at three with me, just, even full at your hour; Muffled as I wild you, even your fashion and your very leg for all the earth, and followed me in so gingerly, that by my troth I must needs say, he was worthy the pleasuring; but in what a taking was I when I perceived his voice? and; when I saw my mistress and; he together by the ears?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: What did thy mistress fight with him?

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.p: O king of heaven, she ran upon his naked weapon the most finely that ever lived, and I ran away in a swoon for fear.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Has she a good courage?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: It seems she is too honest for our companies, a little more good Temperance.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.p: And when he saw me, he called me punk, and pander, and doxy, and; the vilest nicknames as if I had been an arrant naughty pack.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: It is no matter Temperance, he is known and thou art known .

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.p: I thank heaven for it, and there is all indeed, I can stay no longer.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Farewell honest Temperance: how was it possible, Lodouico should fit all these circumstances without the confederacy and treachery of this beldam? well Lodouico must satisfy this doubt when I see him.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: That will be at the May night show at Seignior Honorios.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I would not meet him there, I shall offend him, but there I must needs be, and have thee disguised like a woman.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Me sir?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: No remedy, the Captain Quintilliano and I have devised it to gull his Lieutenant: for thou shalt dance with him, we will thrust him upon thee, and then for his courting and gifts, which we will tell him he must win thee withal, I hope thou wilt have wit enough to receive the one, and pay him again with the the other, come Lionnell let me see how naturally thou canst play the woman.

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Better than you think for.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Come Lieutenant, this nap has set a nap of sobriety upon our brains, now let us sit here and; consult, what course were best for us to take in this dangerous mansion of man's life.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: I am for you i'faith Captain and; you go to consult once.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: I know it Lieutenant, say then what thinkst thou? we talked of employment, of action, of honour, of a company and ; so forth.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: Did we so Captain?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Did we so Ass? 'Sfoot, wert thou drunk afore thou wentest to the tavern, that thou hast now forgotten it?

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: Cry you mercy good Captain, I remember I am your Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Well sir, and so thou shalt be called still, and I Captain, though we never lead other company than a sort of quart pots.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: Shall we Captain, by the mass then let us never have other company indeed .

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why now thou art wise, and hast a mind transformed with main right, and to confirm thee, I will compare the noble service of a feast with the honourable service of the field, and then put on thy hand to which thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: Thank you good Captain, but do you think that war is naught sir?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Exceeding naught.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: Why then sir take heed what you say, for it is dangerous speaking against anything that is naught, I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Thou sayst wisely Lieutenant, I will not then use the word naught, nor speak ill of either, but compare them both, and choose the better.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: Take heed then good Captain, there be some prick eared intelligencers conveyed into some wall or other about us.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: If there were I care not, for to say true, the first model of a battle was taken from a banquet. And first touching the offices of both: for the general of the field, there is the master of the feast, for the Lieutenant General, the mistress, for the Sergeant Major, the Steward, for the Gentleman usher, the Marshall, for master of the Ordinance the Sewer, and all other officers.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: Yet you are reasonable well Captain.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Then for the preparation, as in a field is all kind of artillery, your Cannon, your Demi-cannon, Culverings, falchions, sakers, minions, and; such goodly ornaments of a field, I speak no hurt of them thou seest, I will have nothing to do do with them .

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: Hold you still there Captain.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Besides other munition of powder and shot, and so for the feast, you have your Court, cupboards planted with flagons, cannes, cups, beakers, bowls, goblets, basins and ewers: And more glorious show iwis then the the other, and yet I speak no hurt of the other.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: No I will be sworn Captain.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Besides your munition of manchet, napery plates, spoons, glasses and so forth; Then for your kitchen artillery, there shall you see all your brass pieces mounted in order, as your beef-pots, your cauldrons, your kettles, chafing-dishes, ladies, spits, a more edifying spectacle than your Cannon and; Culvering, and yet I speak no hurt of them neither.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: No Captain, thus far, I go we.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Then sir, as in the field the drum, so to the feast the dresser gives the Alarm, Ran tan tara, tan tan tantara tan.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: O how it stirs my stomach?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: First then sets forward a wing of light horse, as salads, broths, sauces, stewed meats, and other kickshaws and they give a charge, then do the battle join Captain Capon in white broth, Lieutenant calves head.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: That is my place.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Ancient Sirloin, a man of a goodly presence, and full of expectation, as you ancient ought to be, then have you Sergeant Pie-meat, Corporal Cony, Lanceprizado Lark, Gentlemen, Panbakex, and; all the species of a company.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: Would we might fall to the fight once.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why now grows the fight hot man, now shall you see many a tall piece of beef, many a tough capon go down, and here is the trial of a man's stomach, all the while the Artillery plays on both hands, the Canons lay about them, the flagons go off, thick and threefold, and many a tall man goes halting off, some quite overthrown both horse and foot.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: O my heart bleeds.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: That is, thy teeth water. In conclusion, as the remnant of the feast, (I mean such dishes as scaped the fury of the fight) if they be serviceable, are reserved to furnish out another day if they be maimed or spoiled, they are sent abroad to relieve prisons and hospitals. So the remainder of the fight, if they be serviceable, they are reserved to supply a second field, for the fragments of the fight, namely the maimed soldiers, they are sent likewise to furnish prisons and hospitals, how sayst thou now Lieutenant, shall we to the feast, or to the fight?

sp.speaker: Inn.
sp.l: No fighting good Captain, to the feast for Gods sake.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Thou art of my mind right, and so will we presently march on to the sack of the Emperors head, then to the Maynight feast, and show at Seignior Honorios, and there will be a wench there boy, a delicate young morsel, a kinswoman of Seignior Honorios, and her fathers only child, he a mighty rich Clarissimo, and her shalt thou court, win her and wear her, thou hast wit at will.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: But shall that wench be her fathers son and heir Captain?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: she shall be his heir, on mine honesty.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: But shall not my Mistress your wife be at that show?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: she shall, and we could find her; Fannio has been abroad this hour to seek her: the Ass is stepped into some corner or other mourning for my absence.
sp.stage: Enter Angelo and Francischina in disguise.
sp.l: See who comes here?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come Cuz, march fair, methinks thou becomest a Page excellent naturally, cheer up thy heart wench.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Fie for shame kiss in the streets?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Why not? truth seeks no corners, and it was a true loves kiss, and so is this.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Ware riot, dost thou mark Lieutenant?

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Gods pity, my husband.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: What were these Captain?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Upon my life the hindmost of them, is a wench in man's attire, didst thou not mark besides his slabbering about her, her big thighs and her splay feet.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: By the meskin methought they were so indeed .

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: 'slife, the hungry knave her squire, could not hold in the open streets.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: What should she be?

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: The Doxy was muffled in her cloak, I had but a glimpse of her; but 'Slight I will know her, she passes not so, come we will follow.I will beat the Rogue and take away his whore from him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Come courage Cuz, we have sailed the man of War out of sight, and here we must put into harbour. Hist, haw Aemilia?

sp.speaker: Amil.
sp.l: O welcome good Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Here take in, go, get up lightly, away, take heed you slip not Cuz, remember you are short heeled.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: Hold fast for Gods sake.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay hold you fast, you will shame us all else; so Jove receive thy soul: I take away the ladder: Now till you have deceived the Provost, farewell, remember your lesson Cuz.

sp.speaker: Franc.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: How unhappily did we miss them? they slipped into some vaulting house, I hold my life.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Faith it is good we missed them , she was some stale punk I warrant her.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Twenty to one she is some honest man's wife of the Parish that steals abroad for a trimming, while he sits secure at home, little knowing, God knows, what hangs over his head; the poor Cuckold esteeming her the most virtuous wife in the world. And should one tell him, he had seen her dressed like a Page following a knave thus, I will lay my life he would not believe it.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.p: Why no Captain, wives take all the faith from their husbands. And that makes them do so many good works as they do.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Mercy for that i'faith Lieutenant, stand close.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.l: My Mistress in man's apparel sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.l: Thy Mistress in man's apparel I assure thee, and attended by Angelo.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.l: Would to heaven I had seen her, canst tell whither she went.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.l: Full butt into Lorenzoes house, and if thou knewest him, thou knowest wherefore, an ill-favoured trimming is her errand.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: It is very well, she trims my Captain prettily, in the mean time his head pays for all, and yet alas poor horn-stock, he thinks her to have no fault, but her too much dotage upon him, well my conscience will not let me keep her counsel, he shall know on it.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: Why man if both of us should tell him her fault he will not believe us.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: No, nor if he had seen it with his own own eyes I think , I shall never forget how the profound Cockatrice hung on his sleeve today , and he should not from her sight, she would follow him into the wars, one day should make an end of both their loves and lives , and then to see him the wittol, my Captain began to strut, and battle the pride of his merits that so heightened her affection.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: True, and how the soppasty his Lieutenant, stepped in to persuade with her, to take it patiently, for friends must part, we came not all together, and we must not go all together.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.l: Well, it will not be for any man to follow him, if this were known once.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.p: Lord how all the boys in the town would flock about him as he walks the streets, as it were about a bagpipe, and hoot the poor Cuckold out of his horn-case.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.p: Well, if I were worthy to give him counsel, he should even fair and well hang himself.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.l: No, no, keep it from him, and say thou foundest her at a woman's labour.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.l: A plague of her labour, the Captains brows sweat while she labours.

sp.speaker: Giac.
sp.l: If I were in thy case, I should laugh out right when I saw him.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.l: That dare not I do, but as often as he turns his back to me, I shall be here
sp.p: with him that is certain: or when I follow him and his cheating stock Innocentio, in the streets, I shall imagine still I am driving an Ox and an Ass before me, and cry phtroh, ho ptrough.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: 'Slight Captain take this and take all.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Not a word for the world, for if we should take notice of his words the slave would deny all, leave it to me to seize it in private. Now sir, what news with you? where is your Mistress, that you range thus at your pleasure?

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.l: In health sir I trust.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Come forward you rogue you: come forward, whither creep you behind so? where is your Mistress sir?

sp.speaker: Fann
sp.l: At a poor woman's labour sir.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Very well sir, come Lieutenant, go you afore, and do you follow him sir.

sp.speaker: Fann.
sp.l: What afore my Captain sir: you shall pardon me.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Afore you rogue, afore.

body.stage: Enter Honorio, Lorenzo, Gasparo and Angelo.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Seignior Lorenzo, and Gasparo, you are very welcome, we shall have good company and sport to entertain you ere long I hope, shall we not Angelo?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yes sir, I have invited all you commanded me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: This is the honest man indeed, that took the pains to come for me.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: And for me also.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: No pains but pleasure sir, I was glad I had such good means to be known to your Worship.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Nay, I have known you before, to be the servant of Seignior Honorio here, I take it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Not my servant Seignior Lorenzo, but my sons.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: O, your son Aurelios servant? believe me you or your son (in mine opinion, though I say it before him) made good choice of him: for he hath a good honest face, and to a man of judgment (I tell you) that is as good as a good surety for him. I will be better acquainted with you sir, pray you give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Both my hand and heart sir, shall be ever at your service.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Thanks my good friend, I will make thee laugh anon Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I thank your Worship, you have done so often.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: A notable wag Seignior Gasparo.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: How curiously Lorenzo thinks he carries the matter?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How now Gentlemen, is it a merry secret, that you smile so?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: No secret Seignior Lorenzo, but a merry conceit we were thinking on, to furnish our show anon, if it had been thought on in time.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What was that I pray?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Marry sir, we had good sport today with Snail the chimney-sweeper.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Had you so sir?

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: That ever was.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Lord that I had been amongst you, but what more of him sir?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Marry sir, we were thinking how we might merrily deceive our company that is to come, if we could have gotten him some Magnificoes suit of the City, whom for his little stature and lean face he might resemble, that in that habit he might have stolen some kind favours from the Ladies, to make him amends and please him for the anger we put him in.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: It would have made excellent merriment.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You are his best Master sir, and if it please you to send me for him by some token, I will go for him; otherwise he will not come to these Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Shall he come Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: If you please sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why then hark thee Angelo, not for the world.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Think you me such an Ass sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Shall he have one of my little brothers suites, and come in amongst the Dames for him?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: If you could, it would fit him exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Much; now laugh Angelo: what Gentleman was that I spied aloft with my daughter thinkst thou?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I know not sir; I beseech your Worship who was it?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Franke in man's apparel Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: O wonderful.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: We cannot invent a token, for my love Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: O excellent.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: We will hit it anon Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: At your leisure sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: The swaggerer her husband, had note of it by his Page, and yet the same Page hath persuaded him, since that it was but a gullery.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: It is a notable crack; and his Master hath such a pure belief in his wife, that he is apt to believe any good of her.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: True Angelo, enough for this time; thou shalt make as if thou wentest for Snail, and return without him, saying thou canst not find him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Agreed sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen, we have devised a wile to bring Snail amongst us, and I have given Angelo order for a suit for him, that is my little brothers, and him he shall counterfeit; go seek him out.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Thank you for this good Seignior Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: It will quicken the company well.

body.stage: Enter milia, Lionell, Francishina and another woman.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: For their sakes and yours, I have done it Gentlemen; and see the fair flock come upon us.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Welcome fair Ladies, but especially you Lady, that are so mere a stranger, Seignior Lorenzo you know young leonoro?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Very well sir, a gallant spark.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: And I think you know his father.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Know him? I'faith sir there was a reveller, I shall never see man do his lofty tricks like him while I live.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: This Gentlewoman is his Niece sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: His Niece? she shall do herself wrong not to be acquainted with her dear uncles companion:

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: You know not this Gentlewoman sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Not very well sir indeed, but entertainment must be given, mercy Franke for thy man's apparel, a plague of all swaggering husbands. Nay I must forth i'faith, Seignior Honorio, this is for your sake, am I not a kind help to your entertainment?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: An exceeding kind one sir, and I exceedingly thank you.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: The maskers are come sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Do you and your fellows attend them in.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: We will sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Sit gentle Ladies till the maskers raise you to dance.

body.stage: Enter Aurelio, Leonoro, Quintiliano, and Innocentio, in a maske dancing.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Welcome Gallants, O the room is too scant, a hall Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: See how womanly my Boy looks Quintiliano.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: It will be rare sport; Lieutenant, that sweet wench in the branched gown is the heir I told thee of.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: Gods me, I will to her and kiss her.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: O no, you must not unmask.

sp.speaker: Innoc.
sp.l: No, no, I will kiss her with my mask and all.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: No Lieutenant, take her and court her first, and then kiss her.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: To her slave.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: There is thy wife too, Quintiliano.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: True, little knows she I am so near her; I will single her out, and try what entertainment a stranger may find with her.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Do so, and we will take up the the other.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I can by no means find Snail sir.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: The worse luck, but what remedy?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Gramercy Angelo: but Seignior Lorenzo, methinks I miss one flower in this female garland.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Your Niece Lucretia.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: By my soul it is true;what is the reason Angelo Lucretia is not here?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I know no reason but her own will sir.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: There is somewhat in it certain.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: Did you see the play today I pray?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: No, but I see the fool in it here.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: do you so forsooth? where is he pray?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: Not far from you sir, but we must not point at anybody here.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.p: that is true indeed, cry mercy forsooth, do you know me through my mask?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.p: Not I sir, she must have better skill in baked meats than I, that can discern a woodcock through the crust.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: that is true indeed, but yet I thought I would try you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What Nephew Lodowick, I thought you had been one of the maskers.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I use no masking sir with my friends.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: No seignior Lodowick, but you are a very truant in your school of friendship, that come so late to your friends.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Somewhat has crest him sure.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Somewhat shall cross him; Lodouico let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: With me sir?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: You are the man sir, I can scarce say the Gentleman, for you have done a wrong the credit of a Gentleman cannot answer.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Would I might see his face, that durst say so much.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Observe him well, he shoes his face that will prove it when thou darest.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: How now Leonoro, you forget yourself too much, to grow outrageous in this company.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: Aurelio, do not wrong me, and yourself , I undertake your quarrel, this man hath dishonoured your Kinswoman whom (if I might) I intended to marry.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Some error makes you mistake Leonoro, I assure myself .

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: what interruption of our sport is this gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Are not my Nephew and Leonoro friends?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: He charges me with dishonouring his mistress Lucretia.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: By Our Lady Lodouico, the charge touches you deeply, you must answer it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: I only desire I may sir, and then will refer me to your censures.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Well Nephew, well; will you never leave this your haunt of fornication? I school him, and do all I can, but all is lost.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Good Uncle give me leave to answer my other accuser, and then I will descend, and speak of your fornication, as the last branch of my division.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Very well, be brief.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: I will sir; The ground upon which this man builds his false imagination, is his sight of me at back gate, since dinner, where muffled in my cloak, kind Madam Temperance, the attendant of Lucretia, from the Tarrasse, wafted me to her with her hand; taking me (as now I understand) for this honest Gentleman, I not knowing what use she had to put me to, obeyed the attraction of her signal, as gingerly as she bad me. (A plague upon her gingerly) till she locked me into chamber, where lying asleep on her bed, I thought it rudeness to wake her; and (imagining when she waked she had something to say to me) attended her leisure at my ease, and lay down softly by her; when (having chaster and simpler thoughts than Leonoro imagines) because he measures my waist by his own ) in the very coldness and dullness of my spirit, I fell suddenly asleep. In which my fancy presented me with the strangest dream, that ever yet possessed me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Pray God you did but dream Nephew.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: You shall know that by knowing the event of it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: Go to, pray let us hear it.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Methought Lucretia and I were at maw, a game Uncle that you can well skill of.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Well sir I can so.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You will the more muse at my fortune; or my oversights. For my game stood, methought, upon my last two tricks, when I made sure of the set, and yet lost it, having the varlet and the five finger to make two tricks.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How had that been possible?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: That had been no misfortune sure but plain oversight.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: But what was the reason you thought you lost it sir?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: You shall hear; she had in her hand the Ace of Hearts, methought , and a Coat card, she led the board with her coat, I played the varlet, and took up her coat, and meaning to lay my five finger upon her Ace of hearts, up start a quite contrary card; up she rises withal, takes me a dash on the mouth, drew a rapier he had lay by him, and out of doors we went together by the ears.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: A rapier he had lay by him?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What a she turned to a he? dost thou not dream all this while Nephew.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: No not that time neither, though I pretended it; let him be fetched, I warrant you he will show as good cards as the best on you, to prove him an heir Male, if he be the eldest child of his father.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: This is exceeding strange: go Angelo, fetch her and her handmaid.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will sir, if her valour be not too hot for my fingers.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: Could such a disguise be made good all this while without my knowledge? to say truth, she was a stranger to me, her father being a Sicilian: fled thence for a disastrous act, and coming hither grew kindly acquainted with me, and called me brother. At his death committing his supposed daughter to my care and protection, till she were restored to her estate in her native Country.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Was he in hope of it?

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.p: He was, and in near possibility of it himself, had he lived but little longer.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Here is the Gentlewoman you talked of sir, nay you must come forward too grave Mistress Temperance.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: How now sir? who wants gentility now I beseech you?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Stand not amazed, nor disparage him: you see sir, this habit truly doth suit my sex, howsoever my hard fortunes have made me a while reject it.

sp.speaker: Hon.
sp.l: what hard fortunes?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Those you know of my father sir: who feared my following of him in my native likeness, to the haven, where he by stealth embarked us, and would have discovered him, his offence being the slaughter of a Gentleman, that would have slain him.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.l: But did you not tell me you were betrothed before this misfortune happened, to a young Gentleman of Sicily, called Theagines?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: I told you I was betrothed to one Theagine, not Theagines, who indeed was a woman,

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: And yet whosoever had seen that Theagine since might have taken him for a man.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: Do you know her Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Lio.
sp.l: It seems you will not know her.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Hark how my boy plates the knave with her.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: A noble rogue, 'Sfoot Lieutenant, wilt thou suffer thy nose to be wiped of this great heir?

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: 'Slight sir you are no handkercher are you?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Prithee forbear, more happy than unlooked for is this dear accident: adopted and noble father, this is the Gentlewoman to whom I told you I was betrothed, the happy news she had to relate to me, made her a traveller, the more search of her passage made her a Page, and her good fortune obtained her ~~ this honest Gentleman to her Master, who I thank him, being (as she supposed me) loved me, accept us both for your children.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: Most gladly and with no less care, than mine own protect you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: 'Sfoot, how now Leonora? new fireworks?

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: New sir, who wants gentility? this is a gentlemanly part of you to keep a wench in a Pages furniture?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.p: It was more than I knew Sir, but this shall be a warning to me while I live, how I judge of the instrument by the case again.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Nay it is you friend Lodouico that are most to blame, that holding the whole feminine sex in such contempt, would yet play the pickpurse, and steal a poor maids maidenhead out of her pocket sleeping.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It was but to cozen me.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: And to be before me in love.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And to laugh at me.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Nay, jest not at me sweet Gentles, I used plain and mannerly dealing, I neither used the brokage of any, as you know who did Leonoro, nor the help of a ladder to creep in at a wenches chamber window (as you know who did Aurelio.) Nor did I case myself in buckram, and cry chimney sweep (where are you uncle?) but I was trained to it by this honest matron here.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.l: Meddle not with me sir.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.l: I am beholding to her, she was loath to have me lead apes in hell.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Look that you keep promise with me Lady, when will thy husband be from home?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Not so soon as I would wish him, but whensoever you shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: I very kindly thank you Lady.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.l: Gods me, I took you for Seignior Placentia.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: 'Sfoot, thou liest in thy throat, thou knewest me as well as myself.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.p: What, Seignior Qunitiliano, and friend Innocentio, I looked not for you here, and; you are much the better welcome.

sp.speaker: Quin.
sp.l: Thanks dad Honorio, and lives my little squire? when shall I see thee at my house lad?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: A plague on your house, I was there too lately.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: See Lordings, here is two will not let go till they have your consents to be made surer.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: By my soul, and because old Gasparo here has been so cold in his love suit, if she be better pleased with Aurelio, and his father with her, heaven give abundance of good with him.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.l: So you stand not too much upon goods, I say, Amen.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Faith use him as your son and heir, and I desire no more.

sp.speaker: Hono.
sp.l: So will I of mine honour, are you agreed youths?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: And most humbly gratulate your high favours.

sp.speaker: Gasp.
sp.l: Faith and; Jove give them joy together for my part.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: Yet is here another nail to be driven, here is a virtuous Matron, Madam Temperance, that is able to do much good in a commonwealth, a woman of good parts, sells complexion helps maids to services, restores maidenheads, brings women to bed, and men to their bedsides.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.l: By my faith, but save votre grace sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: Hath drinks for love, and gives the diet.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.l: by Our Lady, and that is not amiss for you sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.l: For me, with a plague tee?

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.l: No nor for any man that is not sound I mean sir.

sp.speaker: Lod.
sp.p: 'Sfoot masters these be good parts in the old wench, wilt thou have her Lieutenant?she will be a good stay to the rest of thy living, the gallants will all honour thee at thy house I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Inno.
sp.l: Fore God Captain I care not if I have.

sp.speaker: Temp.
sp.l: Well young Gentleman, perhaps it should not be the worst for you.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.p: Why law, thy virtues have won her at first sight, she shall not come to thee empty, for I will promise thee that I will make her able to bid any Gentleman welcome to a piece of mutton and rabbit at all times.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: By Our Lady, a good Ordinary.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Thou wilt visit sometimes Dad.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That I will i'faith boy in authority wise.

sp.speaker: Quint.
sp.l: Why then strike hands, and if the rest be pleased,
Let all hands strike as these have struck afore,
And with round Echoes make the welkin roar.
